loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel J., who is 24 and single, still lives with his parents, but he is preparing for his future family by striving hard to have a better life. In their village, he operates his family's passenger tricycle. The tricycle carries a minimum of five passengers. He transports passengers from their village to the town proper and other nearby municipalities like Roxasand Ilagan, Isabela. Joel uses the daily income from operating the tricycle to purchase feed for his pigs.

He requests a loan of $100 (4000 PHP) for maintenance of his tricycle and to buy stocks of feed for his pig-raising business. “The amount will be helpful in my business,” said Joel.

loans.use: Maintenance of his tricycle and to buy more feed for the pigs

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Christina K., a 38-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has four children, who are between the ages of 12 and 16 years old.

Christina has been running a charcoal sales business since 2007: these small, black, dirty pieces of dry earth are important to the people of Tanzania because they rely on charcoal to cook meals on a daily basis. Indeed, many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them. Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, the charcoal-selling business is quite lucrative. She works at her business 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, though she notes that she is assisted by one employee. By doing so, Christina currently earns approximately $55 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to purchase more charcoal for resale purposes. In the future, she plans to expand her charcoal business. Christina thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional charcoal

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
“I’ am positive that I will be able to improve my family's life someday and I can generate money to repair our house and send all my children to school,” Myrna said. 

Myrna S. sells different kinds of vegetables, fish, meat, and other items.  She is married to Artemio, who is an expert in pipe repairing and installation. They have two children: Angela is 16 years old, and a senior high school; Army is 9 years old, and in grade three. Due to the irregular income of her husband, Myma decided to sell vegetables, chicken, meat, pork, and fish. 

She now needs additional working capital, and is requesting a loan of $200 (9000 PHP) to purchase more items that she can sell in her store. She is optimistic that her daily income will increase when she is able to increase the variety of products. Also, she plans to use part of the loan to repair their own passenger tricycle.

Myrna always believes that at the right time, God will provide whatever she is asking.

loans.use: Buy more products to sell in her store and repair the passenger tricycle

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
“It’s better to give than to receive” is what Josephine believes in. She always practices this and her experiences prove that it is true, because she has been receiving a lot of blessings from God, like her family’s good health, good business, good relationships with family and neighbors. 

Josephine, together with her husband and three children, live in Brgy. Binarzang Quirino, Isabela. She has a pig-raising business and her husband manages their two-hectare rice and corn fields. She has three pigs, which she will sell for around $200 (9000 PHP) after four months. Thus, she expects to gain more than 50% income from her capital investment.

“Enough capital means more pigs to raise and therefore more income for the business”, said Josephine. So, she is requesting a loan of  $100 (4000 PHP) to increase her revolving capital.  With this capital, she expects to triple her yearly income. 

"I will work harder to provide good education for my children", she added.

loans.use: Buy additional pigs to raise and sell

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Frida M., a 26-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has two children, who are both 3 years old.

Frida M. has been running a stationary business since 2006. The stationary sales business allows micro-entrepreneurs to demonstrate their business savvy; to illustrate, most such entrepreneurs place their shops, stalls, or tables strategically close to post offices, banks, schools, and universities in order to generate as much income as possible. She works at her business 12 hours per day and 6 days per week. By doing so, Frida is able to earn approximately $300 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy a printer and additional paper to better meet her customers' demands. In the future, she plans to increase her inventory of stationary. Frida thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To meet customer demand by purchasing a printer and additional paper

loans.name: Benedicto

texts.en:
“Education is the only gift that I can give to my children,” said the father of the six children from Barangay Malamag East Tumauni, Isabela.

Benedicto S. transports commuters on his tricycle in their community, nearby villages, and to the town's Public Market. He also manages their corn fields.

He is married to Consolacion, who also has a vending/retailing business. They have six children: Benidicto Jr., 6 years old, a day-care student; Kristel, 10 years old, an elementary student; Reynalyn, 12 years old, an elementary student; Francis Ann, 14 years old, a high school student; Hazel, 15 years old and a high school student; and Jenaliza, 16 years old, and also a high school student.

With all his children presently studying in school, he needs more income to support their education. This is the reason why Benidicto requests a loan of $100 (4000 PHP). He plans to use a portion of the loan to purchase brand new rubber wheels, chain, and other parts to maintain his tricycle. He also plans to use the loan to pay for his children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of brand new rubber wheels and other tricycle parts

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Eva M., a 38-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is single and has two children, who are 8 and 12 years old, respectively.

Eva has been running a clothing sales business since 2004. In particular, she sells clothes such as vitambaa (materials), vitenga (African traditional clothes with wax prints), and kanga. She works at her business 8 hours per day and 6 days per week, though she is assisted by one employee. By doing so, Eva is able to earn approximately $80 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy more materials to make more clothes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Eva M. thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional materials

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Christmas season is fast approaching. Christmas lights, Christmas trees, and other Christmas decorations everywhere. Many will crave for foods that are popular during this season like "bibingka" (the famous rice cake).

Josephine is known as the best bibingka maker in their village. She is married to Ferdinand, who is a rice farmer. They are blessed with five children: Jennifer, 24 years old, a high school graduate, works as a family helper in Pangasinan; Joan, 23 years old and also a high school graduate, works as a helper in Manila also; Ferdinand Jr., 21 years old, works as a house carpenter; Albert, 12 years old, already a freshmen in high school; and Judy Ann, 9 years old, in grade three. They live in Minallo Naguillan, Isabela, which located a few kilometers away from the town center. The village is a small rural area with roads along the mountainside.

Aside from making the best bibingka in their town, she also makes good cassava cakes. Her business is doing great, but she wants to increase her revolving capital. So she is asking for a loan of $325 (15000 PHP). She plans to use the money to buy raw materials for making rice cakes like native rice, cassava, brown sugar, coconuts, cheese, and other ingredients. She also wants to purchase a motorized grinder to easily and quickly grind the rice and cassava. In addition, Josephine wants to purchase two heads of piglets for their backyard piggery. She plans to use the rest of the loan to repair of their house.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for rice cakes, buy 2 piglets, and make house repairs

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Aisha K., a 28-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is single and has two children, who are 5 and 8 years old, respectively.

Aisha has been running a tailoring business since 2006. Indeed, she purchases vitambaa (materials), vitenge (traditional Tanzanian clothes with wax prints), and kanga (printed cotton fabrics, often with borders along all four sides) and makes them into clothing, primarily for women. She works at her business 12 hours per day and 6 days per week, though she is assisted by one employee. By doing so, Aisha is able to earn approximately $295 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy additional vitambaas, vitenges, and kangas. In the future, she plans to add even more clothes to her inventory. Aisha thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional materials, clothes, and fabrics

loans.name: Mercedez

texts.en:
“Sincerity and patience are the attitudes that a businesswoman like me must have. In every business dealing, I always wear my friendly smile to gain others' sympathy and trust,” Mercedes said. 

Mercedez Y. is married to Bernardo Y. Sr. and they are blessed with five children. The eldest is an elementary graduate, 37-year-old Bernardo Y. Jr.; followed by Freddie, 36 years old, a high school graduate; Bernadette, 30 years old, and a college graduate; Karen, 29 years old, a high school graduate; and Gerald, 18 years old, an elementary graduate. Her two eldest sons are working abroad as drivers in Dubai, and the other two work in their rural place at San Mateo Quirino, Isabela. 

Mercedez is a direct dealer of personal products for young and old people. Sometimes, she also sells ready-to-wear (RTW) clothes. She is able to earn at least $25 (1200 PHP) net income per week. She wants to improve her business to prepare for their future, especially now that she is 59 years old. 

To fulfill her plans, she is requesting a loan of $200 (9000 PHP) to further increase the quantity of products she sells and, therefore, earn more income.

loans.use: Buy more products to sell

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Mariamu M., a 39-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has four children, who are between the ages of 3 and 15 years old.

Mariamu has been running a tailoring business since 2006. She purchases vitambaa (materials), vitenge, and kanga (printed cotton fabrics, which often have a border along all four sides), and she makes them into clothing, primarily for women. She works at her business 8 hours per day and 6 days per week. By doing so, Mariamu is able to earn approximately $120 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to purchase three sewing machines. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mariamu thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing three sewing machines

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Hawa A., a 26-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has two children, who are 2 and 4 years old, respectively.

Hawa has been running a cosmetic sales business since 2006. In particular, she sells women’s cosmetics. She works at her business 12 hours per day and 7 days per week. By doing so, Hawa is able to earn approximately $300 per month from her business operations. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy more women's cosmetics for resale purposes. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Hawa thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normA. make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional women's cosmetics

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou R., 52, is married and lives with three of her children and her husband in the Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She sells cake and makes $3 a day. She makes the cake from sticky rice, bananas, salt, sugar, coconut, and other ingredients. Her husband is a grocer and makes $3 a day as well. 

Mrs. Nou R. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to add more grocery products. This will allow Nou R. and her husband to attract more clients. (Nou R. is pictured with her husband outside their home.)

loans.use: Add grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong S., 53, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Prey Veng province, Cambodia. One of their children is a student and the other is a taxi driver. Since 2000, she has sold rice and other food in the village to earn a living.  She is able to make $3 a day.  Her husband sells fermented fish in the market and he usually makes $5 a day. 

Hong S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase more fermented fish from individual fishermen. (Hong S. and her husband are pictured outside their home.)

loans.use: To purchase fermented fish to sell.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah O. is a 46-year-old mother of four children who are all in school. She is very hard working and resourceful. She sells charcoal in her neighborhood. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all traditional Ghanaian homes. Hannah obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages and sells it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase savings to pay for her children’s educational fees. She is a member of the group called Liberty Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans. She is grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy bulk supply of charcoal.

loans.name: Song

texts.en:
Mr. Song R., 54, is a widower and lives with three of his children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Since 1990, he has been selling coffee and grocery products, and also working as a police official. On average, he makes $5 a day and is aided by two of his three children who are workers. 
 
Mr. Song R. would like to take out a loan of $500 to add to his grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To add grocery items to his inventory.

loans.name: Ngveng

texts.en:
Ngveng T., 39, lives with her husband and four children in the Prey Veng province, Cambodia. Three of their children are students and one is too young to attend school. She typically makes $4 each day, selling various kinds of dessert. Her husband is a mechanic, fixing motorbikes and bicycles. On average, he makes $5 a day. 

Ngveng T. would like to take out a loan of $750 to purchase tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase tools.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Asha B., a 45-year-old woman from Mwanza. She is married and has two children, who are 10 and 26 years old, respectively. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting another dependant (an orphan--his parents did not care about him, so Asha took him into her family).

Asha has been operating a beauty salon since 2006. At her beauty salon, customers are able to buy any type of hair (long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, or blue hair) for their head, then have such hair attached to their heads, woven, cut, or braided, and finally made to look like their own hair. She works at her business 12 hours per day and 7 days per week, though she is assisted by 2 employees. By doing so, Asha is able to earn approximately $600 per month from her business operations. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $425 in order to buy more salon products (e.g., weaving materials, short hair, long hair, and curly hair). In the future, she plans to increase her inventory of hair care products. Asha thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services. Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her. As such, one of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional salon products (e.g., weaving materials, short hair, long hair, and curly hair)

loans.name: Oam

texts.en: Oam M., 44, is married and lives in the Prey Veng province with her husband and two children. She raises pigs and makes approximately $4 each day, while her husband makes $5 a day working in construction. Inflation has made prices soar lately in Cambodia, and Oam M. realized that she needed to expand her business to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase construction tools for her husband. She sees this loan as a great economic opportunity and believes that she can raise her standard of living through her careful investment.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
“In sickness and in health, for richer and for poorer, ‘til death do us part”. Julia and her husband, Manuel, still hold the marriage vows they took during their wedding. 

For many years, Manuel has worked as a farmer. With six mouths in the family to feed in, he and Julia strive to work harder to be able to sustain their everyday living expenses. Julia owns a store in their small community of Sisim Alto. She earns an average income of $20 (1000 PHP) per week, which is just enough for their daily consumption and assistance for their rice farming. To purchase additional products to sell in her small store, she is requesting a loan for $125 (5000 PHP). They expect that this amount will help them make their business grow. 

They are motivated to manage their store well because they do not want to depend on the support of their children, who also have their own families. Julia believes that “when there is hardship, there is progress”.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell in the store

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn R., 55, is married and lives with her husband and four children in the Prey Veng province. She works as a farmer together with her husband growing rice and beans, and they typically make US$3 every day. They are also supported by one child who works in a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has forced food prices to skyrocket. These factors have caused a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these difficulties, Sorn R. is asking CREDIT for a loan of US$1200 to purchase fertilizer, rice seeds, and gas. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that the business venture will be successful. (Sorn R. and her husband were not available for the picture, so her daughter is pictured instead.)

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, rice seeds, and gas.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
“My interest in managing my store has become my passion,” Antonia said.

Antonia C. lives in Cabisera 18, Ilagan, Isabela where they plant a variety of vegetables, including corn, and rice. She is married to Romel who is a tricycle driver. They are still childless, but they are praying hard to have their first baby.

She has run a small store in their village for almost seven years. Antonia works hard and patiently and treats her customers well. She is requesting a loan of $150 (7000 PHP) as additional working capital. She earns about $10 (500 PHP) a week. Antonia says, “I’m optimistic that I can double my income if I would have the needed capital for my business." Antonia plans to use the loan to buy different products to sell in her store.

Antonia has a reputation in their community for having good credit, and she plans use the loan properly so she can pay back the loan. She also dreams of having a better life and a happy family through God’s grace and have her own children in the future.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell in the store

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheng L., 53, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. One of their children is employed in a private company, and one is a student.  She raises pigs and makes approximately $4 each day.  Her husband is a teacher; he makes $3.50 a day as well to help support the family.  
Mrs. Cheng L. would like to request a loan of $1200 to add more pigs to her stock and purchase feed for them.  (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To expand her stock of pigs.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun S., 52, is married and lives with her husband and five children in the Prey Veng province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3 each day. Her husband fishes and grows rice. Her husband makes about US$2.50 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also contributed to the high prices. Hun S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase more groceries and fertilizer. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase grocery and fertilizer.

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa A., a seamstress, is married to Emiliano, a livestock raiser. They have four children: the eldest is Elizabeth, 32 years old, married, and an elementary graduate; Jonnifer, 29 years old, married, and a high school graduate who works as security guard; Ricky, 24 years old, also is a high school graduate, who works as a messenger; and Janice, 20 years old, a high school graduate, who works as a sales lady in Manila.

To expand her business, Leonisa requests a loan of $100 (4000 PHP) to purchase another sewing machine. The business is generating a good income, especially during the start of classes and when there are sports festivals and weddings. Most of her co-villagers bring their clothes to her for repair.

Leonisa cannot cope when she has a lot of customers, so she wants to buy a sewing machine and hire one seamstress to help her in her business so that she will able to satisfy her clients’ demands.

Her increased income will be a big help in providing their daily needs. Also, it can supplement her grandchildren’s allowances everyday.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Rath

texts.en:
Rath A., 64, is a widow and lives with her two children in Prey Veng province. One child works in a garment factory, and the other is a motorbike taxi driver.  She grows rice and vegetables, earning around $2 each day.

Mrs. Rath A. has requested a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike so her son can operate a motorbike taxi business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to use in a taxi service.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B., 40, is married and has six children. Three of her children have completed senior high school and the oldest is now in the second year of university studies. She is a very resourceful wife and mother who works hard to support the family. Mary supports her husband in providing for the household by selling used clothing. Selling used clothing is a very big business in Ghana because brand new clothing is too expensive for the poor. Mary wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She is member of the group called Liberty Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans. She is grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
The Municipality of Naguillan in Isabela is known for its delicious native rice cakes. That is why Lilibeth is very proud of selling her homemade native rice cakes to her fellow villagers.

She is married to John, who paints buildings and houses. They only have one daughter, named Joanna, who is 2 years old now. She hopes that somehow she can save for her child's education.

Lilibeth is requesting a loan for $100 (4000 PHP) as additional working capital for her business. She plans to purchase native rice, brown sugar, coconuts, raisins, cheese, and other ingredients for her homemade cakes. She also accepts made-to-order special rice cakes for different occasions. Sometimes, because she lacks the funds, she is not able to buy the ingredients to prepare her cakes, so some of her customers go to other rice cake makers in the village. Lilibeth would be thankful for the chance to get the loan so that she can meet the orders of her customers and earn more income for her family.

Lilibeth and her husband are working hand-in-hand for the future of their daughter. They want to give her good education, which will be her stepping stone towards a better life. Lilibeth and John would also like to pursue their rice cake business so they will be known in their village and nearby municipalities as producers of good quality and delicious products.

loans.use: Buy the ingredients to make baked goods

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena O., 51, is married and has six children. Two of her children are married and living with their spouses, and the others are still in school. She is a very resourceful wife and mother who works hard to support the family. Abena supports her husband in providing for the household by selling used clothing. Selling used clothing is a very big business in Ghana because brand new clothing is too expensive for the poor. Abena wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan will help her save for her children’s future education and also allow her to rent a permanent store. She belongs to the community group called “Kristo Tease” (Jesus lives) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans.

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of fruits

loans.name: Pomaah

texts.en: Pomaah A. is married and has eight children, three of whom are still in school. She lives with her family in Obuasi, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is 62 years old.  For the past four yeas, she has sold ladies and children’s clothing such as skirts, underwear, and slippers. She needs a loan to inject more working capital into the business. She believes the loan will help her to purchase good quality clothing so she can upgrade her inventory, and then she will be better able to provide for her three children who are still in school. She belongs to the community group called “Kristo Tease” (Jesus lives) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans. She is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase clothing

loans.name: Atakola Lending Group

texts.en: M. Annet, 31, is the leader of Atakola lending group in Jinja. She is married with 4 children and she cares for 1 niece. Annet has a retail shop that she has owned for 4 years while she has been a member of her group for 2 years. She is quick to say that life is different since she started getting loans because now she has a lot to sell and therefore more profits. She is grateful that now she is even able to save for her future plans as regards her children. Annet sells sugar, salt, cooking oil, detergents and many other things and she would like a loan to buy more goods for her shop.

loans.use: More sugar, salt, cooking oil for her shop.

loans.name: Fatimata-Touré

texts.fr:
Madame T. est âgée de 47 ans et elle a pour l’activité la vente des bijoux et des sacs de sortie.  Elle achète quelques produits à Cotonou, la capitale du Benin, et les autres articles au grand marché de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle les revend à Agoè, un quartier au nord de Lomé ou elle habite.  Elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 2004.  Elle a une fois bénéficié d’un crédit au près de WAGES, et elle a bien remboursé.  Avec ce deuxième crédit, elle peut acheter 40 complets de bijoux et 2 douzaines de sacs de sortie.  Avec ce nouveau stock, elle peut servir ses clients pendant les fêtes de fin d’année, parce que les choses qu’elle vend peuvent servir de très bons cadeaux pour les femmes.
Madame T. est née à Sokode, une ville située 175 km de Lomé.  Elle est mariée avec un revendeur et ils ont 4 enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. is 47 years old and sells jewelry and handbags. She buys several products in Cotonou, the capital of Benin, and she buys other products at the large market in Lomé, which is the capital of Togo. She sells these products in Agoè, an area in the northern part of Lomé where she lives. She has been involved in this since 2004. She has taken out one previous loan with WAGES, and she repaid the loan in full. With this second loan she is requesting, she can purchase 40 sets of jewelry and two dozen handbags. With this new stock she will be able to serve her customers during the year-end festivals, since the goods that she sells make very good gifts for women. Mrs. T. was born in Sokode, a city situated about 175 km from Lomé. She is married to a retailer and they have four children.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of jewelry and handbags

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa B. is 48 years old, married,  and the mother of five children who are currently in school. She has manufactured palm oil for 20 years. Palm oil is produced from palm fruits. Palm oil is used to prepare many local dishes. Her production is on a small scale because she does not have enough money to buy a machine for the processing. She wants to use the loan to buy more palm fruits and an electric milling machine so she can produce the oil in larger quantities. She believes this increased production will augment her income so she can better support her family and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called “Kristo Tease” (Jesus lives) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans.

loans.use: To buy palm fruits and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Mastora

texts.en:
Mastora lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives with her own nuclear family. She works in tailoring now and she can also work in embroidery. For a long time, she was involved in embroidery but during the last 2 years, she has been working in tailoring and she has some good numbers of customers. She wants to make some changes in her working there and since she needs more working capital, she wants to take a loan.

Now she has applied to take out an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani with a term of 12 months to buy necessary materials to further her business with more success and help her family.

Mastora is very happy with this loan process. She has plans within the next few years to have a big shop with lots of workers. She said, "I will continue my partnership with Kiva and AFSG in future."

loans.use: To  buy necessary materials for working as a seamstress

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia D. is 34 years old, married, and has five children who are all in school. She is a very hard working and resourceful mother. She sells charcoal and smoked fish in her neighborhood in Obuasi. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all traditional Ghanaian homes. Afia obtains her charcoal from the surrounding villages and resells it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supply of charcoal and smoked fish to sell to her customers. She hopes to increase her savings so she can pay her children’s educational fees. She belongs to the community group called “Kristo Tease” (Jesus lives) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans. She is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and smoked fish.

loans.name: Addul Rafiou

texts.fr:
Monsieur D. A. a un magasin ou il vend les produits d’alimentation générale depuis 2006.  Il a une fois bénéficié d’un crédit de 300,000 CFA ($600) au près de WAGES, qu’il a bien remboursé.  Ce deuxième crédit va lui permettre d’acheter 12 sacs du riz, 15 bidons huile, 10 cartons de pate alimentaire, 12 cartons de biscuits, 11 cartons d’eau minérale, et 10 cartons de pate dentifrice.  Il va acheter tous ces produits chez les grossistes au grand marché de Lomé, et les revend à Agoè, un quartier au nord de Lomé.  
Monsieur D. A. est célibataire et il a un enfant à sa charge.  Il est né à Kpalime, une ville située 120 km au nord de Lomé où il y a beaucoup de montagnes et cascades.
texts.en:
Mr. D. A. has a store where he has been selling groceries since 2006. He once received a loan from WAGES in the amount of of 300,000 CFA (USD 600), he paid it back completely. This second loan would allow him to buy 12 bags of rice, 15 drums of oil, 10 boxes of pasta, 12 boxes of cookies, 11 boxes of mineral water, and 10 boxes of toothpaste. He buys all these products at wholesalers at the large market in Lomé and resells them in Agoè, a neighborhood north of Lomé. Mr. D. A. is single and his financially responsible for one child. He was born in Kpalime, a town located 120 km north of Lomé where there are a lot of mountains and waterfalls.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat des produits d’alimentation générale

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S., 28, is a resident of Kompong Tom Province. She makes a living selling a few groceries out of her home as well as raising fish in her pond near her house. She currently has three children, all of whom are minors and are living at home.

San S. is married to Chouy Lay, 35, who sells ice-cream for kids. He runs his business out of a motorcycle trailer, going from village to village, specially in the schools, and can earn approximately US$ 5 per day. S. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries for sale and to replace their old motorcycle-trailer for her husband to use to sell ice-cream. (She and her two daughter are pictured.)

loans.use: To buy more groceries for sale and a new motorcycle trailer

loans.name: Baligema Lending Group

texts.en: Joan N.  is married with children, the eldest being 16 years old while the baby is 3. For the past six years, she has been selling goods from her retail shop in Jinja town. She buys her stock from the wholesale shops in Jinja and Iganga at a discount and then sells at a retail price. She is among the many people that have benefited from getting loans and her loan uses range from owning a plot of land of her own, paying school fees for her children with almost nothing as a contribution from their father, plus many others. Joan seeks another loan to be able to buy more shop goods like sugar, maize flour, and many others.

loans.use: buying more sugar, maize flour, and many other items for her shop

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty G. is 39 years old, married, and has five children, who are all in school. She lives with her family in Obuasi, in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood. Gifty is a very skillful and talented hairdresser. With six years of experience, she has three apprentices who are currently training under her. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore, she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, hair-dryer machines, and so forth to serve her customers better. She belongs to the community group called “Tumi wura” (Almighty) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans. She is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy salon supplies

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina H. is 40 years old. She is married and has five children who are currently in school. She has manufactured palm oil and palm kernel oil for six years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts, and palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. These oils are used to prepare many local dishes. She produces the oils and supplies them to food vendors to prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil. 

Georgina will use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine so she can produce the oils in larger quantities. She believes this increased production will augment her income so she can better provide for her family and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called “Tumi wura” (Almighty) Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua A. lives in Asokwa, a suburb of Obuasi in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. She is 35 year old, married, and the mother of five children; three are in senior high school and two are in junior high school. She sells tomatoes and other food items like beans, maize, yam, cooking oil, and salt fish on top of a table in the local market. She does not have sufficient working capital to run her business profitably. With the loan, she will purchase good quality stock to upgrade her inventory and the increased income will enable her to provide her children with a good education so they can have a better future. Akua is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase food items to sell

loans.name: Mirmen Pashtoan

texts.en:
Mirmen Pashtoan lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with 4 children; two of them are married and the other two are single, but Pashtoan wants her son to marry and she is faced with some economic problems concerning his wedding. When she found AFSG, she was really very happy and after completing documents she applied for a loan.

Pashtoan wants to take out an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani with a term of 12 months to buy the necessities for the wedding of her son so her son can marry as soon as possible. She wants to say that after this wedding, she is sure that she can repay this loan on time.

She is very happy with this process of small loans; she said it is a great program of loans in Afghanistan. Everyone can use these loans and she would like to thank the people around the world that help people of this country.

loans.use: To buy necessities for her son's wedding

loans.name: Iganga Road Group

texts.en: Suzan N. is married with 4 children, all in school. For the past six years, she has been selling used clothing for women, men, and children from Jinja Market. She buys her stock from the large market in Kampala and some times from Jinja, from the recently opened stores, at a discount and then displays the items for sale at a higher price. For the stall in the market, she pays a daily fee to the authorities and with her loan, she plans to buy a bale of used clothes for her stock. By buying in larger quantities, Suzan can get a larger discount, hence more profits. She has been a member of the Iganga Road group for 2 years.

loans.use: Buying a bale of used clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence F., a.k.a FF, is 40 years old. She is married and has three children who are currently in school. She has manufactured palm oil for five years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. She produces the oil and supplies it to food vendors so they can prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine so she can produce the oil in larger quantities. She believes this increased production will augment her income so she can better provide for her family and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called House of Faith Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married with grown-up children. She owns a clothing sales business. Her gross monthly income is 8,000 UAH, and her investment in inventory is 40,000 UAH.

Valentina started her own business 5 years ago. Her friends got involved in this kind of business a few years earlier. She saw that their experience was positive and decided to try herself. The business grew little by little. Valentina found out she had great communication skills and financial aptitude that allowed her to develop her business. Now this business helps Valentina to be financially and socially independent.

Valentina would like to get a loan of 5,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. She pays special attention to good quality in choosing her goods. Her clients respect her and often come back for new clothing. Valentina hopes that increased assortment will allow her to offer her customers a better choice and increase her sales.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida A. is 28 years old. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She has been sewing for four years. She is a specialist in female clothing. She sews various kinds of styles that give her customers a new look, such as kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, and so forth. She wants to use the loan to buy sewing materials like linen, threads, and thimbles to increase her productivity. She hopes to increase her savings so she can provide her children with quality education. She is a member of the community group called ‘Tumiwura’ meaning Almighty Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee the repayment of the loans for one another. Her picture was taken during her group meeting. She is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah K. is 50 years old, married,  and the mother of four children. She manufactures palm kernel oil. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil, which is used to prepare many local dishes. Her operation is on a limited scale because she does not have sufficient capital to buy machines for processing the oil. She is requesting a loan so she can buy more raw material (palm kernel) and the processing equipment that will help her to produce palm kernel oil in larger quantities. She believes this increased production will augment her income so she can better provide for her family and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called “Tumi wura” (Almighty) Trust Group. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To buy palm kernel and the equipment to process it

loans.name: Mohammad Nasim

texts.en:
M. Nasim lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives with his own nuclear family. He is the only one to support his family. He has a retail shop and he has been involved in this business for more than 5 years. During this time he has attracted some good numbers of customers. He would like to make his business stronger, and therefore he needs some money.

He has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani with a term of 12 months to complete his stock and start working hard to be more successful in his business. Nasim said, "I am sure that after a period of time I will be a good retailer."

He is happy.He wants to thank AFSG for this process of loans in Afghanistan that helps the poor people in this country to become successful and help their families to educate their children. In future, he wants to thank lenders around the world.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Chhea

texts.en: Mrs. Chhea L., 42, resides in Kompong Tom Province. She owns and runs a media store in her home, renting and selling CDs but also groceries as well. She started her business about eight years ago, earning an income each day of $3. She now cares for two children, both of whom are still young. Her husband, Sok Savin, age 42, is both a construction worker and motorcycle taxi driver. Savin can't attract customers because his motorcycle often has problems, therefore Savin and L. have requested a loan to buy a new motorcycle to replace the old one.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes S. is 44 years old. She is married and has ten children. Three of the children are currently in school. She has manufactured palm oil from palm nuts for 20 years now. She produces the oil and supplies it to food vendors so they can prepare their meals. She will use her loan to buy more palm nuts and an electric milling machine so she can produce the palm oil in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and increase her income so she can support her husband, provide food for her family, and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Born Again Trust Group. Her picture was taking during their group meeting. Members in this group guarantee the repayment of the loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Akoélé

texts.fr:
Née à Avétsèdomé en 1971, madame Akoélé T. s’est mariée à un mécanicien avec qui, elle a eu trois (03) enfants.
Gérante d’une boutique, elle vend un peu de tout. Sa localité qui est très reculée de la ville, fait que toutes les bonnes femmes viennent s’approvisionner chez elle. Sa capacité de financement très limitée fait qu’elle a souvent des ruptures de stock.
Pour y remédier, elle sollicite un appui financier qui servira à approvisionner sa boutique de tous les produits de premières nécessités afin d’avoir de nouveaux clients.
texts.en:
Born in Avétsèdomé in 1971, Ms. Akoélé T. married a mechanic with whom she has three children. The manager of a shop, she sells a little of everything. Her town, which is very remote, is the reason all the good and honest women go to see her for their supplies. Because of her very limited ability to obtain financing, she often has inventory shortages.

To remedy the situation, she is requesting financial support for acquiring supplies for her shop with all the basic provisions in order to have new customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her shop with merchandise

loans.name: En

texts.en: En H. is 49-year-old resident in Kompong Tom Province. He is married with two children, both of whom are students and are living at home. His wife, Thorn Choun Neung, is 39 years old. They are chefs for a restaurant in an area in their community, cooking all kinds of foods including Khmer Food or Chinese Food. They have much experience from a long time ago and both currently get salaries of $300 per month. H. and Choun Neung are seeking a loan to build a restroom and for improving their house.

loans.use: To build a restroom and improve their house

loans.name: Odette Djigbodi Ama

texts.fr: Célibataire avec un enfant, madame Odette Djigbodi Ama K. est née à Alokoègbé dans la préfecture de Zio le 08 juin 1968. Après ses études secondaires prématurément arrêtées, elle entra en apprentissage de la couture, métier qu’elle n’arrive pas à exercer parce qu’elle ne dispose pas de moyens financiers pour ouvrir un atelier. A force de courage et de détermination, elle entreprit un petit commerce de pagnes. Elle va de villages en villages, les jours de marché pour vendre les pagnes qu’elle achète à crédit auprès de ses fournisseurs. Pour renforcer son activité commerciale et assurer son autonomie financière, elle sollicite un financement sous forme de prêt. C’est une femme dynamique et digne de confiance.
texts.en:
Ms. Odette Djigbodi Ama K. is unmarried and has one child. She was on June 8, 1968 in Alokoègbé, Zio Prefecture. Following her secondary schooling, prematurely halted, she entered into a sewing apprenticeship, work that she has not been able to practice because she lacks the financial means to open a workshop. Backed by courage and determination, she undertook small-scale commerce in pagnes (colorful West African cloth). She goes from village to village on market days to sell pagnes that she buys on credit from her suppliers. To bolster her commercial activities and to ensure her financial independence, she is requesting financing in the form of a loan. This is an energetic woman who is worthy of trust.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in "pagnes"

loans.name: Jeannette Akagbe

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Accra, madame J. A. est mariée à un mécanicien auto et mère de six (06) enfants. Elle aide son mari à travers son petit commerce de préparation et de vente de la bouillie « zogbon » à base de maïs. Elle fait souvent face à des ruptures de stock en produit de base et sollicite un financement pour constituer un stock suffisant de maïs.   Ce commerce lui permet beaucoup d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins de la famille et dans la scolarisation des enfants.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Accra, Ms. J. A. is married to an auto mechanic and is the mother of six. She assists her husband with her small business making and selling "zogobon" cornmeal porridge. She often faces inventory shortages of essential ingredients and is requesting financing to build a substantial inventory of corn. This business very much enables her to help her husband address the needs of the family and the children's schooling.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock corn for making and selling porridge

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Medical Supplies

loans.name: Baba

texts.fr:
Madame BATANA baba est une femme motivée qui a ouvert un débit de vente de boissons en casiers et charbons dans le quartier de djidjolé à Lomé (Togo), ce commerce marche bien et elle le fait depuis 1998. Elle s’approvisionne au marché local de tsotsi pour les charbons et au point d’approvisionnement de la brasserie du togo. Elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de WAGES, elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour pouvoir acheter des casiers de boissons et des sacs de charbons.
Elle est mariée avec Mr BRANGAMA tombégou qui est un entrepreneur, ils ont trois enfants. Avec le profit tiré de ce commerce, elle pense aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes du foyer.
texts.en:
Ms. Baba BATANA is a motivated woman who opened a outlet selling beverages in cases and charcoal in the Djidjolé district in Lomé (Togo). She has been in this business since 1998, and it is doing well. She gets her supplies at the local marketplace of Tsotsi for charcoal and the supply point of the Togo brewery. She has never been a recipient of a WAGES loan and is requesting this initial loan to buy cases of drinks and sacks of charcoal.

She is married to Mr. Tombégou BRANGAMA, an entrepreneur. They have three children. With the profit derived from this commerce, she is planning to assist her husband with day-to-day household expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Madame A. Akossiwa est née en 1970 à Djagblé où elle a grandi. Mère aujourd’hui de six (06) enfants, elle a appris la boulangerie, métier qu’elle exerce dans son quartier et qui lui procure l’essentiel de son revenu. Mariée, elle est obligée de se débattre au quotidien pour faire face aux besoins de ses enfants et surtout pour garantir leur avenir. Actuellement, elle connaît des difficultés liées à l’augmentation du prix de la farine de blé sur le marché ; ce qui a fait chuter sensiblement sa production. 
Pour remédier à ce problème qui pèse sur les conditions de vie de sa famille, Madame A. sollicite donc un financement pour stocker la farine de blé et le bois afin d’éviter des moments de rupture et accroître ses revenus.
texts.en:
Ms. Akossiwa A. was born in 1970 in Djagblé where she grew up. A married mother of six, she learned how to bake, which is work that she has been doing in her district and that brings in most of her income. She must struggle each day to cope with the needs of her children and especially to guarantee their future. Currently, she is experiencing difficulties linked to the market price increase of flour, which caused her production to drop noticeably.

To remedy this problem which is heavily affecting her family's living conditions, she is therefore requesting financing for an inventory of flour and firewood in order to prevent inventory shortages and to grow her income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock flour for her bakery

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr:
Menuisier de formation, Monsieur A. Kokou est né en 1967 à Gapé. Marié et père de six (06) enfants, il exerce avec détermination et professionnalisme son métier. Ce qui lui confère une réputation notoire et une sollicitation de toutes parts. Il entretient de très bonnes relations avec de grands services, des institutions, entreprises qui lui confient souvent des marchés à réaliser et qu'il n’arrive plus à satisfaire face à l'augmentation des prix des planches sur le marché. C’est pourquoi il voudrait aller dans les fermes et villages pour s’approvisionner en gros et constituer ainsi un stock important de planches afin de servir à temps les clients et décrocher d’autres marchés importants qui l’échappent aujourd’hui faute de moyens financiers.
Ainsi sollicite-t-il un financement pour réaliser son vœux le plus cher de manière à s’imposer dans son quartier.
texts.en:
Mr. Kokou A. was born in 1967 in Gapé, he is a carpenter. He is married and the father of six children, he practices his trade with determination and professionalism. This confers him a good reputation and orders from everywhere. He has very good relations with large service industries, institutions, businesses that often give him contracts and he cannot meet the demand anymore because of the increase in the price of boards. This is why, he would like to go to farms and villages to buy in bulk and build up a large stock of boards. That would allow him to serve his clients on time and to obtain other large contracts that he can't currently get because he lacks the financial means. Thus, he is requesting a loan to fulfill his dearest wish and to establish himself in his neighborhood.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stoskage de bois et planches

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Cette dame de trente huit (38) ans d’âge  à Adidogomé est une revendeuse de produits de beauté dans le quartier d’Adidogomé un quartier de Lomé non loin de l’ONG « IJD ». Elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2003. Elle na jamais obtenu de crédit de chez WAGES, la demande ayant augmentée, elle sollicite ce crédit pour s’approvisionner en mèches, chaussures et sacs de dames.
Elle est mariée avec Monsieur ANANI Prosper et ont ensemble trois (03) enfants. Avec les revenus tirés de ce commerce, elle compte aider sa famille dans les charges quotidiennes du foyer.
texts.en:
This 38 year old woman sales beauty products in the neighborhood of Adidogomé in Lomé, not far from the NGO "IJD". She practices this business since 2003. She has never received a loan from WAGES, but the demand has increased so she is requesting a loan to buy extensions, shoes and women's purses.

She is married to Mr. Prosper ANANI and together they have three children. With the income from this business she will help with the family's daily expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of extensions, shoes, and women's purses.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Madame Akossiwa A. est âgée de quarante deux ans (42), elle vend des articles de mercerie dans le quartier d’adidogomé awatame. Elle fait cette activité depuis 2005 et a déjà obtenu un crédit de 150 000 de WAGES qu’elle a remboursé sans difficultés. La demande est très forte surtout en ces périodes de fêtes de fin d’année. Elle sollicite un deuxième crédit qui lui permettra de s’approvisionner en articles de mercerie pour convenablement répondre à la demande.
Madame AFAMEHE a deux (02) enfants et est mariée à FOLLY Ata qui est un électricien.
texts.en:
Mrs. Akossiwa A. is 42 years old, she sells sewing supplies in the neighborhood of Adidogomé Awatame. She has practiced this activity since 2005 and has already received a loan of 150,000 from WAGES that she paid back in full. The demand is very high especially at this time of end of the year festivities. She is requesting a second loan that will allow her to stock up on sewing supplies in order to meet the demand. Mrs. AFAMEHE has two children and is married to Ata FOLLY who is an electrician.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sewing articles

loans.name: Kpakpo

texts.fr:
Né le 04 octobre 1975 à Aného, Monsieur A. Kpakpo est célibataire avec deux (02) de ses frères et sa mère à charge. Exerçant le métier de photographie, il tire l’essentiel de ses revenus de là pour nourrir sa famille et se prendre en charge. Très populaire et sollicité de par la qualité de ses services rendus, il se trouve confronté à un problème de déplacement ; ceci a fait chuter sensiblement son chiffre d’affaire et a affecté son niveau de vie. 
En effet, il n’arrive plus à répondre aux nombreuses sollicitations et beaucoup de ses clients se dirigent vers d’autres photographes. Face à cette situation aux conséquences incalculables, il sollicite un financement pour se doter d'un appareil photos plus performant et d’un moyen de déplacement afin de récupérer ses clients et surtout accroître son chiffre d’affaires susceptible de relever le niveau de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Kpakpo A. was born on October 4, 1975 in Aného, he is single and is financially responsible for his brothers ' two children and his mother. He is a photographer and derives most of his income comes from this trade to feed his family and support himself. He is very popular and gets a lot of requests because of the quality of his services. He is faced with a transportation problem, consequently his income has dropped somewhat and this affects his standard of living.

Indeed he can no longer meet all of the demands and a lot of his clients are going to other photographers. Faced with this situation with untold consequences, he is requesting a loan to buy a better camera and a mean of transportation in order to get his clients back and mostly to increase his income and to hopefully raise his family's standard of living.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a camera and a mean of transportation for his work

loans.name: Amélé

texts.fr:
Veuve avec sept (07) enfants, Madame D. Amélé est née en 1947 à Aného où elle mène son activité depuis une quinzaine d’années. Seule face aux charges de la famille, elle se débat jour et nuit afin de garantir leur avenir. Boulangère très réputée et reconnue dans le quartier, elle est très sollicitée partout. Face à la demande de la clientèle, et surtout à l’augmentation sans cesse du prix de la farine de blé, Madame D. Amélé se propose d’acheter en gros la farine de blé et de les stocker. Cela nécessite de moyens financiers dont elle ne dispose pas. Aujourd’hui elle sollicite un crédit pour acheter des sacs de farines de blé pour éviter la rupture et d’autres augmentations de prix.
Ledit financement permettra à Madame D. d’avoir d’autres clients et satisfaire à tout moment les besoins de la clientèle sans cesse grandissante.
texts.en:
A widow with seven children, Ms. Amélé D. was born in 1947 in Aného, where she has been working for some fifteen years. Alone in facing family expenses, she struggles day and night to guarantee her children's future. As a highly-renowned baker well-recognized in her district, she is in great demand everywhere. Faced with the customer demand, and especially with the ever-increasing price of flour, she had the idea to stock up in bulk. This requires financial means she doesn't have. Today, she is requesting a loan to buy sacks of flour to avoid inventory shortages and more price increases. The aforementioned financing will enable her to have additional customers and to satisfy at all times their ever-growing needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock flour for her bakery

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr:
Née en 1970 à Lomé, Madame K. Dédé est mariée et mère de cinq (05) enfants. Son mari conducteur sans emploi et les revenus dégagés par Madame K. Dédé seule ne suffisent pas à couvrir les besoins de la famille.	
Elle s’est engagé à donner une autre dimension à son activité afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus croissante des clients et par conséquent disposer de revenu stable susceptible de permettre à sa famille de joindre les deux bouts. Elle sollicite alors un crédit pour s’approvisionner en boissons, savons, chaussures et autres. Ce financement aidera cette famille à améliorer son niveau de vie et aussi pour l’épanouissement de la famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Lomé, Ms. Dédé K. is married and the mother of five. Her husband is an unemployed driver, and the income earned by Ms. K. alone is insufficient to cover family needs. She has dedicated herself to giving her business another dimension to satisfy the burgeoning customer demand and consequently to have a stable income that may enable her family to make ends meet. She is therefore requesting a loan to get supplies of beverages, soap, shoes, and more. This financing will help this family improve its standard of living, so that it can thrive.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her shop with merchandise

loans.name: Félicienne Dédé

texts.fr:
Célibataire avec trois (03) enfants, Madame H. Dédé Félicienne vit seule avec ses enfants dont l’avenir lui tient tant à cœur. Aussi se débrouille-t-elle chaque jour pour subvenir à leurs besoins les plus élémentaires. Pour ce faire, elle va de marché en marché pour acheter de la farine de manioc ou "gari" qu’elle revend à la frontière Togo-Bénin. 
Très reconnu de par son dynamisme et la qualité de ses produits, elle est de plus en plus sollicitée. Mais ses moyens sont très limités actuellement. C’est pourquoi Madame H. forte de son expérience antérieure de petit crédit, sollicite aujourd’hui un financement pour acheter en quantité considérable les produits afin de couvrir toutes les demandes qui s’adressent à elle.
Le financement de ce micro entrepreneur contribuera à n’en point douter à assurer son autonomie financière et accroître son chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
Unmarried and having three children, Ms. Dédé Félicienne H. lives alone with her children whose future she takes to heart. Also, she manages to get by each day providing for their most basic needs. To do so, she goes from marketplace to marketplace to buy cassava flour or "gari" that she resells along the Togo-Benin border. Renowned for her dynamism and the quality of her merchandise, she is in demand more and more. But her means are currently very limited. This is why Ms. H., having a wealth of experience from previous micro-loans, is today requesting financing to buy goods in considerable quantities to cover all the orders sent to her. The financing of this micro-entrepreneur will, without any doubt at all, help ensure her financial autonomy and to grow her sales figures.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in cassava flour

loans.name: Gulzoda

texts.ru: Нурманова Гулзода 28 лет она замужем . Она сидит дома и ухаживает за скотом. Её отец  и муж  помогают в разведение скота, выводя скот на продажу на рынок . Их основной скот козы и овцы. Для откорма скота  им помогает отец, потому что у него есть опыт по откорму скота: он знает как кормить, и в течении какого времени кормить коз или овец.  В течении  месяца она кормит их комбикормом и овсом для того что бы скот быстрей поправился они используют особую технику кормления. Потом они продают скот на рынке. Сразу же отец советует купить скот  взамен проданного скота, что бы можно было также откормить и продать очередной скот. Такой цикл купли продажи и откорма скота позволяет Гулзоде и ее семье содержать семью и погашать во время кредит.  Муж  Гулзоды помогает в этом , потому что он часто не бывает дома, он уезжает на заработки в другие страны.  Пока у них нет детей, ей легко ухаживать за скотом, когда появятся дети, ей в бизнесе помогут муж и её отец.
texts.en:
Gulzoda N. is 28 years old and is married. She stays home and takes care of farm animals. Her father and husband help with growing the livestock for the market. Goats and sheep are their primary animals. Gulzoda’s father is very experienced and knowledgeable about the animals’ proper diet. The goats and sheep are given the feed and oats monthly in order to accelerate their growth. Once fully grown, the animals are sold at a market. The father advises to purchase new livestock right away to feed them for the market again. This cycle allows Gulzoda and her family to support them and to repay their loan on-time. Gulzoda’s husband is often gone because he travels to other countries for work to help support the family. They have yet to have children, so it is easy for Gulzoda to take care of the livestock now. Her husband and father will help with the business once she has children.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase livestock count

loans.name: Raymond Yaovi

texts.fr:
Monsieur A. Yaovi Raymond est un jeune de 24 ans qui vit à Adidomé. Très dévoué et étant très instruit, il s’est lancé dans le commerce de pagne qu'il vend de marchés en marchés et dans lequel il réussit bien. Pour sécuriser son revenu, il est impératif qu’il dispose d’un fond de roulement. C’est dans ce souci qu’il sollicite un crédit.
Ce crédit lui permettra de faire le stockage de toutes les variétés et qualités de pagnes afin d’élargir son étalage. La réalisation de ce projet lui permettra d’améliorer ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaovi Raymond A. is a young man, 24 years old, who lives in Adidomé. He is very devoted and, being well-educated, he got started in the commerce of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) that he sells from marketplace to marketplace. His is successful in his business. To secure his income, it is imperative that he has working capital. With this concern in mind, he is requesting a loan which will permit him to create an inventory of all the varieties and grades of pagnes to expand his display. The success of this project will enable him to improve his living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell "pagnes"

loans.name: Houndjénouko

texts.fr:
Mariée et mère d’un enfant, Madame A. Houndjénouko est âgée de 20 ans et vit actuellement à Avéglidjigan dans la préfecture de VO. Son petit commerce d’alimentation générale et divers lui permet de participer à la gestion de son ménage.
Sa compétence en matière de gestion de fonds lui a permis de maintenir son étalage quoique de petite taille. Elle nécessite un fonds de base sur lequel elle aura à tourner. Cela lui permettra de pouvoir approvisionner son étalage en marchandise et améliorer son revenu.
texts.en:
Ms. Houndjénouko A. is married and a mother with one child. She is 20 years old and currently lives in Avéglidjigan in Vo Prefecture. Her small business in groceries and sundry items enables her to help manager her household. Her competence in managing funds has allowed her to maintain her display of goods, small though it is. She needs working capital that she will operate from. This will enable her to stock up on merchandise and to improve her income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To supply her display of basic goods

loans.name: Association Elom-Agoè Adjougba Group

texts.fr:
Située dans le quartier Agoè Adougba dans la ville de Lomé (Togo), l’association ELOM-agoè Adougba est une association crée  depuis  février 2008 et composée de cinq (5) femmes dynamiques, toutes clientes de WAGES : madame A. missadji, S. hodalo, B. labosso, Z. jeannette, T. dagoe pour la plupart divorcées de leurs maris et ont toutes des enfants à charge. Cette association exerce dans le commerce d’alimentation dans le marché d’Aogè et s’approvisionne au marché d’Anié, de Blitta, de notsè et surtout au grand marché de lomé.
Cette association a déjà obtenu deux crédits de 250,000F et  300,000F auprès de WAGES qu’elle a remboursé sans problèmes, elle sollicite ce troisième crédit pour agrandir son stock avec 02 sacs et demi de maïs, 01 sac et demi de mil, 02 sacs de riz, 01 sac de haricot, 11 sacs de charbons de bois, 05 paniers de légumes, 40 douzaines de balais, 03 paniers de petits poissons.
texts.en:
Located in the Agoè Adougba district in the city of Lomé (Togo), the association ELOM-Agoè Adougba was created in February 2008 and is composed of five energetic women, all WAGES clients: Ms. Missadji A., Hodalo S., Labosso B., Jeannette Z., and Dagoe T.. Most are divorced from their husbands and all have children to look after. This association is in the food business at the Agoè marketplace and gets its supplies at the marketplaces of Anié, Blitta, Notsè, and especially at the grand marketplace of Lomé.

This association has already been the recipient of two loans of 250,000 francs and 300,00 francs with WAGES that it repaid without a problem. It is requesting this third loan to expand its inventory by two and a half sacks of corn, one and a half sacks of millet, two of rice, one of beans, eleven of charcoal, five baskets of vegetables, forty dozen brooms, and three baskets of small fish.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain, charcoal, vegetables, brooms, and small fish

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is currently in the business of selling fresh fish and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Mary is 31 years old and is divorced. She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open a restaurant

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sodjidi

texts.fr:
