Yolanda is engaged in the vending business. She put up a small stall in front of their house where her customers go when they needed to buy something. Some of her merchandise includes fish and meat. Her store is located beside their small furniture shop which is managed by her husband. The couple is working hand in hand to make sure that they can provide the needs of their family and the education of their two children.

She dreams of improving her business so she requests a loan of PHP 10,000.00 which will serve as additional capital for her vending business. She will buy additional products to sell in her store in order to increase her income. She also saves some of her income for them to have enough money to renovate their house.

loans.use: Yolanda would like to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita and her family live in the small village of Sitio Guingab. “Sitio” means an extended small group of houses within kilometers but still covered by a large but typical Barangay. She is 54 years old and married to a simple upland farmer and they are blessed with 11 children. Most of their children are high school and college undergraduates and two of them are still studying and already in their high school level.

She has managed a small village store for 15 years. She is thankful that she can earn at least PHP 2,500 gross income a week which they utilize to sustain their daily needs such as food, school allowance for their children and as rolling capital for her store. Teresita wants to make her business grow so she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000.00. This amount will serve as her capital to purchase additional stocks for her store so she can meet the demands of her customers. “We all help each other to improve our lives and we are hoping that our two children will pursue their studies hard and hopefully earn a college degree”, Teresita said.

loans.use: Teresita would like to purchase additional stocks for her store.

location.town: Sitio Guingab, Masipi East Cabagan, Isabela

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
“I believe that through faith and hard work, I will somehow achieve my dreams in life and I am always willing to wait for that right time,” Luciana says with her belief that in God’s time they will be blessed. Luciana C. is 39 years old and married to Hector, a diligent farmer. They have two children: Mark Anthony – 15 years old, a senior high school student and Melvin – 13 years old, a freshman in high school. Her family is living in the urban area of Old San Mariano, Isabela where they need to ride a ferry boat to when their place was being flooded.

She is operating a sari-sari store (a community based store) in their village. She is glad that she is earning a weekly income of PHP1, 000.00. However, this income is not enough to meet all the needs of their family. So Luciana would like to request a loan of PHP10, 000 to purchase more stocks for her store. This amount will definitely improve not only her business but also her income someday. Her business is of great help in their family and with the education of their children. She hopes to have a progressive family and through their diligence and hard work, everything is possible.

loans.use: Luciana would like to purchase more stocks for her store.

location.town: Old San Mariano, San Mariano Isabela

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
“I believe that hard work is the best thing that a person should do to fulfill his or her dreams in the future,” Marife said. This is her guiding principle in life in reaching her dreams for her family and for her business. Marife M., 37 years old, is the mother of two and married to a farmer and tricycle operator named Johnny. Her two children are Helen Grace – 19 years old, a junior Information Technology student and Marjorie – 11 years old, currently in grade six. She hopes to send them to school until they finish college. They are presently living in Barangay San Mateo Quirino, Isabela, a rural area with a flat surface and rough road where most of the residents are engaged in farming.

Aside from their income from their passenger tricycle Marife has also beenmanaging a school canteen for three years and a hog raising business in their backyard. Her weekly net income is being budgeted for their daily expenses, school allowances of her children, feeds supply for pigs and some serve as revolving capital in her school canteen. To sustain her business' undertakings, Marife would like to request a loan of PHP7, 000. Dreaming of uplifting their life through their business is what she aims. Marife said that to be able to achieve her dreams, she needs to be patient enough.

loans.use: Marife would like to sustain her business' undertakings

loans.name: Jerocelyn

texts.en:
“In order to succeed in life, we must not give up and never lose our hopes” said Jerocelyn Pascual, a 23 year old vendor of a variety of foods, vegetables, fish and meats in their village of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela. She is still single and lives with her parents.

“Engaging in that kind of business is my way of helping my parents to earn for a living,” Jerocelyn added. Jerocelyn ventures into a vending business wherein she sells viands, different kinds of vegetables, fish and meat and snacks. She hopes to increase her capital so she is encouraged to avail a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to improve her vending business since it is doing well in the village. She will do her best to improve her business because she wants to have a better future in the long run and when she has her own family in the right time.

loans.use: Jerocelyn would like to improve her small store.

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
Fermeldy is one of the 46 barangays of the Tumauni municipality. Jesusa said that their village has a community project known as Clean and Green wherein everybody is obliged to plant a variety of edible vegetables in their own backyard. In their village, aside from planting vegetables, villagers mostly plant corn and rice.

Jesusa is married to Estalito, a farmer. They have eight children: Rovick- 6 years old, in kindergarten, Jayrick- 9 years old, in grade three, Romnick- 12 years old, in grade five, Laila- 15 years old, in second year high school, Michelle- 17 years old, in fourth year high school, and the other three are Nickson- 18 years old, Helena- 23 years old and Cristina 28 years old, all graduated from high school.

Jesusa is engaged in selling rice in their community. She buys one sack of rice from their public market and then retails it to their village. With her limited capital, she decided to avail a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 which will be used to purchase an additional two sacks of rice and eventually she will resell it to her regular customers. If her business would grow, she would be able get a license and register it in their barangay so that she could avail and sell large volume of rice the next time.

As long as her children still want to continue their studies up to college, she is willing to support and motivate them so that they will have chances of getting a good job after their graduation. To attain her dreams, she will work hard.

loans.use: Jesusa would like to buy more rice to resell to support the education of her eight children.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en:
According to Eulalia, their Barangay Fermeldy in Tumauini, Isabela can be considered as a model village since it is full of vegetables growing, as the result of their local Barangay Council's effort in implementing the Clean and Green campaign in the community. Eulalia cooperates in this effort by planting edible vegetables like eggplant and other vegetables in front of their house.

She put up a small store in their village to help her husband Stalafeno, a farmer who patiently cultivates their corn field. They are blessed with seven children: Babyline, 13 years old, a junior high school student, Dolfino, 16 years old, Adoracion, 18 years old, Ruby–Ann 20 years old, Vicky 23, years old, and Reysie 25 years old, who are elementary graduates. The eldest daughter is Rosalinda, 26 years old - a high school graduate.

Eulalia earns a weekly income of PHP750 from her store and she wants to increase this by increasing her stocks which is why she wants to avail additional working capital amounting to PHP4, 000. She plans to purchase stocks for her store like biscuits, candies, laundry and bath soap, canned goods, cooking oil, sugar ,salt, coffee, milk, etc.

“Aside from expanding my business, I also want to be able to help my husband to raise the necessary amount to repair our house in the future,” Eulalia said. Though most of their children were not able to finish their studies, Eulalia wants her youngest daughter Babyline to get a college degree.

loans.use: Eulalia would like to purchase more stock of items to sell in her store to support her seven children and send the youngest to college.

loans.name: Hayat

texts.en: Hayat is a 43-year-old widow who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with her child. She has owned a grocery and clothing store since 1996. Hayat sells clothes, food and candy. She requested a loan of $500 US Dollars from Al Majmoua in order to reimburse her debts. This is her second cycle and she has always paid on time. When she first started her business, she didn’t have enough cash, but now, the loans have been helping her improve her income. In the future, she plans to purchase more merchandise for her shop.

loans.use: Hayat needs the loan to reimburse her debts.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is fifty-nine year old Martha M. from Mwanza. She is widowed with four children, between the ages of twenty and thirty. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants who are orphans.

Martha has been running a shop selling different commodities since 2005. This client’s business is in selling maize flour, Kilimanjaro beer, Konyagi beer, cooking oil, wheat flour, margarine, soaps, and sugar. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week. Martha currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to buy more stock of beer for resale. In the future, she plans to increase the range and amount of stock. Martha thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more stock of beer for resale.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia considers the education of her children as the best treasure that she can give them because it is the only treasure that will not fade away. That’s why she wants to assist her husband to raise income for their daily living. She is married to Felix Sr. who is a government employee.

She has five children: Cristian Rick, 11 months, Katrina, 8 years old and in grade two, Felix Jr., 12 years old, a grade 5 student, Liezel, 15 years old and a junior high school student, and the eldest daughter is Rachelle Cany, 16 years old and in fourth year high school.

In order to increase the volume of her stocks in her village store, Eugenia wants to avail a loan amounting to PHP 5,000. The loan will be used to buy different merchandise like detergent /bath soap, toothpastes, canned goods like sardines, corned beef, meat and beef loaf, sugar, salt etc. With the additional capital she needs, Eugenia will be able to increase her income in order to buy food, clothing and finance her children who are still studying.

loans.use: Eugenia would like to purchase different products for sale in her store to raise money for her children's education.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is forty-one year old Justina S. from Mwanza. She is widowed with four children, between the ages of sixteen and twenty two. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants because they are orphans.

Justina has been running a tailoring business since 2002. This client’s business is in selling vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and makes them into clothing, mainly for women. She works at the business for eight hours per day, six days per week, and is assisted by two employees. She currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to buy more materials for making clothes to sell. In the future, she plans to buy two more tailoring machines. Justina thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more materials for making clothes to sell.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
“The loss of my husband did not become a hindrance for me to keep moving and working for our daily living,” a widow from Barangay Malamag East Tumauni, Isabela, said. Gloria has a small store in their village which is a few kilometers away from their provincial highway of Tumauni. Last August 2008, her husband died and left her and their three children.

Aside from managing her business, she is also an active member of their church and acts as the treasurer in their center. She wants to avail a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to increase her revolving capital. “I plan to buy one piglet for my backyard piggery. I keep myself busy so that I can forget the death of my husband,” Gloria said. Though she is not thinking yet of the education of her children because they are not studying yet, she wants to continue her business and engage in other lines of livelihood so that she can earn more income for her children and for herself in the future.

loans.use: Gloria would like to improve her store to provide for her children.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is forty-six year old Tabitha B. from Mwanza. She is married with six children, between the ages of ten and twenty six.

Tabitha has been running a shop since 2005. This client’s business is selling cosmetics. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week. Tabitha currently earns about 150 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to buy more cosmetics for resale. In the future, she plans to open a new shop selling clothes. Tabitha thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
“I was running out of stock that’s why I need to buy additional sacks of rice,” Epifania says. Epifania P. is engaged in rice selling at Tumauini Public Market, Tumauni, Isabela. She is married to George who once was a Barangay Captain in their village, and now manages their farmland. Their four children are already professionals: Joyce, 34 years old, is a nursing graduate, Michael 37 years old, is an engineer, Jose, 40 years old, is a business administration graduate and Marilyn, 42 years old, is a teacher.

For almost 28 years of being in the rice business, Epifania was able to support the studies of her four children and supported their daily living at the same time. Even though she finished supporting the education of her children, Epifania never stopped working hard for their future. She wants to avail a loan amounting to PHP 23,000 as additional working capital. Her business requires large capital because the price of rice is very high and the demand is continuously increasing. Compared to other basic foods, rice comprises the major source of food and energy of everyone. With a lot of competitors doing the same kind of business, Epifania has a strong determination and dedication to work hard so that her business will survive.

loans.use: Epifania would like to buy more rice to sell.

loans.name: Dyagombwa

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is thirty-two year old Dyagombwa N. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, aged five and ten. Dyagombwa has been running a beauty salon since 2005. This client’s business is in selling long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, and blue hair, and then having it attached to your head, woven, cut, or braided, and made to look like your own. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by two employees.

Dyagombwa currently earns about 600 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to buy more women's long hair for resale. In the future, she plans to open another beauty salon. Dyagombwa thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more women's long hair for resale

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a 29-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their child. He has been working as a tailor for five years. Mohamed sews all kind of clothes and fabrics. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new sewing machines.

Mohamed is special in his work because of his good reputation. When he first started his business, he wasn’t able to rent sewing machines in order to work. He decided to start his own business because he has enough experience and also his willingness to continue. In the future, he plans to own a sewing factory.

This is the first time that Mohamed has requested a loan.

loans.use: Mohamed needs the loan to purchase new sewing machines.

loans.name: Zenaida Maria

texts.es:
La microempresaria Zenaida Maria B. P. tiene 40 años de edad es casada con 4 hijos los cuales se encuentran estudiando en nivel primario y secundario. La señora B. se dedica a la venta de ropa usada desde hace 5 años y con este negocio a encontrado una alternativa para poder lograr el sustento diario tanto para sus hijos como para ella, su marido se encuentra en el desempleo por lo que dependen únicamente de este negocio. 

En los últimos años la venta de ropa usada ha venido teniendo una gran demanda de la población ya que se puede comprar tanto ropa de vestir como algunas piezas para las camas tales como sabanas, sobre camas etc.

Sin embargo la microempresaria B. requiere el financiamiento para la compra de:

1 paca de sabanas usadas las cuales compra a US$ 240 cada paca, 1 paca de ropas para niños las que compra a US$ 160 cada paca y 1 paca de ropa variada para adultos a US$ 200 cada paca.
texts.en:
Zenaida Maria B. P. is 40 years old and runs a small business. She is married and has 4 children who are currently attending school. For 5 years now, she has sold second hand clothing, and with this business she has found a way to help sustain not only her children but herself as well. Her husband is currently unemployed, so the family depends entirely on her income.

In the last few years, there has been a great demand for used clothing, as well as other second hand items such as sheets, bedspreads, etc. Senora B. will use the loan to purchase sheets, children's clothing and clothing for adults.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase used sheets, and second hand clothing for children and adults

loans.name: Isai

texts.es: Hola mi nombre e Isai Z. me dedico a la venta de flores y plantas hornamentales en la feria del agricultor, este queda ubicado en el Barrio los Graneros, las ventas las realizo los Viernes y los Sabados, en este momento necesito un prestamos para aumentar mi inventario de plantas y asi poder tener mayores ventas, mi negocio se llama Mercadito Verde, con este credito tambien deseo comprar herramientas para que me permita ser mas eficiente en mi trabajo. de este negocio dependen mis hijos y gracias a el puedo darles alimentacion y estudio.
texts.en:
Hello my name is Isai Z., and I sell flowers and decorative plants in the agricultural fair which is located in the neighborhood of Los Graneros. Sales take place on Fridays and Saturdays. At the moment, I need to make a loan to improve my inventory of plants and subsequently increase sales. My business is called Mercadito Verde. With this loan, I also wish to purchase tools that will allow me to be more efficient in my work. My children depend on my business, which thankfully allows me to provide them food and education.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of plants

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lila Margarita

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Lila E., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva, estoy casada y soy madre, tengo mi pequeño negocio el cual me genera ingresos para ayudarle a mi esposo con los gastos de nuestro hogar, para esta epoca de navidad necesito un credito para poder comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener mas variedad de productos y tambien mejorar las ganancias, las cuales las necesito para darles una mejor calidad de vida a mi familia.
texts.en:
Hello my name is Lila E., and I sell new clothes. I am married, and I am a mother. I have my small business which generates income to help my husband with our living expenses. This time around Christmas, I am asking for a loan to purchase more merchandise and consequently offer a greater variety of products to improve earnings. This is what I need to give my family a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Domingo Rufino

texts.es:
El Sr. Domingo Rufino Zeledón A. es originario de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 64 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Rosa López quien  vende tortilla la cual devenga un salario mínimo que no cubre todos los pagos de los gastos básicos, ambos tienen 5 hijos mayores de edad. Sin embargo estos viven en sus propias casas y también tienen  limitantes económicos.

Hace 13 años El Sr. Zeledón  hace sorbetes caseros sus clientes son los transeúntes que la prefieren por  ofrecer productos caseros. El  Sr. Zeledón no cuenta con el capital necesario para comprar en grandes cantidades los ingredientes de su producto, por eso necesita comprar: 1 quintal de  azúcar a $ 38.00  dólares el  quintal y 4 caja de leche a $ 28.00 dólares la caja, con esta inversión podrá  aumentar su ganancia.
texts.en:
Domingo Rufino Z. A. is originally from the city of Bluefields. He is 64 years old and married to Rosa Lopez. Rosa sells tortillas, but only earns a small salary from this and it's not enough to cover basic costs. They have five grown children who live in their own houses, but still have limited income.

For 13 years, Mr. Z. has been selling home made ice creams. His customers are those passers by who prefer his homemade product. He does not have the money he needs to buy ingredients in large quantity. The loan will be used to purchase sugar, milk and other necessary ingredients to increase his income.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sugar and milk for his ice cream business

loans.name: Las Tres Hermanas Group

texts.es:
hola nosotras somos el grupo las Tres Hermanas, somos mujeres muy luchadoras y que nos conocemos hace mucho tiempo y nos llevamos muy bien casi como hermanas por eso es el nombre de nuestro grupo, somos muy felices con nuestras actividades diaras las cuales nos ayudan para cubrir con los gastos de nuestras familias, nuestro grupo se integra asi:
Maria V.: soy la cordinadora del grupo tengo varios años de fabricar tortillassoy madre soltera y de mi dependen mis dos hijos.
Isidra R.: ella se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de golosinas, tambien vende mercaderia, ella sale a vender su producto de forma ambulante en zonas vecinas y de esta manera se gana la vida, ella es viuda entonces la carga del sustento del hogar es para ella sola.
Reina F.: ella se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de piñatas, tambien ella labora dos dias a la semana en una casa como empleada domestica, ella le ayuda a su esposo para el mantenimiento del hogar. todas nosotras necesitamos este credito para sacar adelante nuestros pequeños negocios.
texts.en:
Hello we are the group Tres Hermanas. We are fighting women and have known each other for a long time. We get along very well, almost as sisters, and for this reason it is the name of our group. We are very happy with our daily activities, which help us to cover our family expenses. Our group also includes: Maria V.: I am the Coordinator of the group have several years experience making tortillas. I am a single mother, and my two children depend on me. Isidra R.: She manufactures and sells sweets and also merchandise. She sells her product on the street in neighboring areas and thus earns a living. She is a widow and the burden of maintaining the household falls on her alone. Reina F.: She manufactures and sells piñatas. She also works two days a week at a home as a housekeeper. She helps her husband with the maintenance of the home. We all need this credit to move forward with our small businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dorotea Marlyn

texts.es:
La Sra. Dorotea Marlyn Hernández García es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 38 años de edad, es madre soltera  de 9 hijos menores de edad,  cinco de ellos estudian en la primaria y los otros en la secundaria, cabe señalar que los servicios básicos, alimentación, vestimenta y educación son pagados con el único ingreso de la venta de ropa y calzado. 

La Sra. Hernández vende ropa y calzado hace 2 años teniendo como clientes a los habitantes de su barrio y los transeúntes  que la prefieren por ofrecer una variedad de ropas (ropa para niños, sabanas, ropa para hombres y mujeres de todas las edades). 

La Sra. Hernández no cuenta con el capital suficiente para comprar mas ropa y por esta razón quiere comprar: 6 unidades de shorts a $ 9.00 dólares la unidad, 6 unidades de pantalones a $ 8.00 dólares la unidad, 6 unidades de sabanas a $ 9.00 dólares la unidad, 6 unidades de toallas a $ 5.00 dólares la unidad, 6 unidades de camisetas a $ 5.00  dólares la unidad y 2 docenas de falda a $ 17.00 dólares la docena, con esta inversión aumentara sus ganancias  y podrá satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Dorotea Marlyn H. G.is originally from the city of Bluefields. She is 38 years old and is a single mother of 9 young children. 5 of her children attend primary school and the others are in secondary school. She has to pay for all the basic costs to provide food, clothing and education for her children with her income from selling clothing.

She began her business 2 years ago with clients from her neighborhood and those passer by who liked the variety she offered, including childrens clothing, men's and women's clothing, and bedding. She does not have enough money to purchase the clothing in the quantities she needs. The money will be used to purchase shorts, pants, sheets, towels, blouses, skirts. With this investment she will be ablet o grow her income and better meet the requests of her customers.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her clothing business, grow her income and continue to provide for her young children

loans.name: Maria Rosa

texts.es: hola mi nombre es Maria R. cuento con mi propio negocio de costura el cual manejo hace varios años,  tengo muchos clientes, tambien hago ropa para caballero solo camisas, para damas hago de todo tipo de ropa, mi taller es pequeño y tengo la ayuda de una prima con la mano de obra, yo necesito un credito para poder comprar una maquina de cocer industrial para mejorar la calidad de mi trabajo ya que las exigencias de mis clientes son muchas, asi tendre mayores ventas y por ende mayores ingresos. soy madre soltea y tengo un hijo de cuatro años de edad el cual solo depende de mi, nosotros vivimos con mi familia ya que es muy dificil alquilar o comprar una casa, deseo tener una oportunidad para poder salir adelante con mi hijo.
texts.en:
Hi my name is Maria R.. I have my own sewing business which I have managed for several years. I have many customers. I also make clothing; for men, I only sell shirts, and for ladies, I make all types of clothing. My studio is small, and my cousin assists me with work. I need a credit to buy an industrial sewing machine to improve the quality of my work to meet the many demands of my clients. This will increase sales and therefore increase revenues. I am a single mother, and I have a four-year-old son who depends on me. We live with my family as it is very difficult to rent or purchase a house. I hope for the opportunity to give my son a good education in life.

Translated from Spanish by Carrie Ting, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: La Era Group

texts.es:
hola nosotras somos el grupo LA ERA, somos cuatro mujeres, y todas residimos en la Col. Nueva Era de la Ciudad de Tegucigalpa, Johanna B. soy la Cordinadora del grupo y tengo 23 años de edad, Glenda Xiomara tiene 34 años de edad. Zonia C. tiene 29 años de edad y Nancy M. tiene 27 años de edad, todas somos muy jovenes y nos dedicamos a la fabricacion y venta de tortillas, Glenda Velasques se dedica a la venta de ropa. en las mañanas tmuy temprano fabricamos la primera ronda de tortillas las empacamos y las vendemos, despues del medio dia hacemos otra produccion para la venta de las 4 de la tarde en adelante, actualmente la demanda ha incrementado mucho y no nos damos abasto para cumplir con todos los pedidos, necesitamos el credito para poder tener una mayor produccion y asi mismo tener mayores ventas y ganancias, nuestra otra compañera vende ropa y ella necesita el credito para comprar para la epoca de navidad que las ventas de ropa son muy buenas.
estamos seguras de que vamos a salir adelante.
texts.en:
Hello, we are with the group La Era. We are four women who all live in the city of Tegucigalpa. I'm Johanna B., I'm 23 years old and I'm the coordinator of the group. Glenda Xiomara is 34 years old, Zonia C. is 29 and Nancy M. is 27 years old. We are all young and work making and selling tortillas. Glenda sells clothing as well. Very early in the morning, we make the first batch of tortillas which we pack and sell. In the middle of the day, we make another batch to sell from 4 in the afternoon onwards. The demand for the tortillas has grown a lot and we can hardly cope with all of the requests. We need the loan so that we can make greater quantities and increase our sales and our income. Our other colleague needs the loan to purchase clothing for the Christmas season, as clothing sales are going well. We are confident that we will continue to grow our business.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in their business making and selling tortillas

loans.name: Gabriel Eduardo

texts.es:
EL señor Gabriel Eduardo es originario de Monterrey, Nuevo León; pero tiene 4 años viviendo en Nuevo Laredo y ha decidido establecerse en esta cuidad. Actualmente está alojado en casa de sus familiares y él agradece a ellos su aceptación durante todo este tiempo, sin embargo menciona que ya es hora de tener su propio techo.
En este momento ha iniciado los trámites para poder adquirir una vivienda por medio de Infonavit (Crédito Gubernamental), pero el valor de la casa es superior al crédito que puede recibir. Solicita su colaboración para realizar uno de sus más grandes sueños.
Él trabaja con ejecutivo de ventas en la central de autobuses en está ciudad; su sueldo es moderado y le es imposible pagar el saldo restante con ello.
texts.en:
Gabriel Eduardo is orginally from Monterrey in Nuevo Leon, but he's been living in Nuevo Laredo for 4 years now and has established himself in this city. He is living in the house of some friends, and he appreciates their help during all this time, but it's now time for him to find his own place. At the moment, he has started the process to buy his own home through an organization called Infonavit, (government credit), but the value of the property is more than the credit he can receive. He is requesting a loan to be able to realize one of his greatest dreams. Gabriel works in sales at the central bus station. His salary is moderate, and he won't be able to cover the difference with only that.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make a sufficient payment for government assisted housing

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.es:
Don Juan, trabaja en una empresa de trasportes en el puesto de descargador e inventario y como todo padre siempre está al pendiente de la salud de sus hijos, en este momento se presentó la necesidad de operar a su hija del paladar y la boca.
Es un gasto fuera del presupuesto familiar, le es imposible cubrirlo y acude ante nosotros para que podamos apoyarlo, le complacerá enormemente toda la ayuda que ustedes le puedan brindar para la operación de su pequeña.
texts.en:
Don Juan works in a transportation company loading inventory. Like all fathers, he is always thinking about the well being of his children. Right now, there is a need for one of his children to have an operation on her palate and mouth. As this is an unexpected expense, it's impossible to cover it unless he can get some help. He greatly appreciates the help you can give for his daughter's operation


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To help cover the costs of an operation for his daughter

loans.name: Markayan

texts.id: Markayan adalah seorang penjual sate yang saat ini tinggal di Denpasar. Dia sekarang berusia 45 tahun dan tinggal bersama istri dan anaknya di perumahan Dalung Permai dengan menyewa tempat. Halaman depan rumah yang disewanya dipakai sebagai tempat untuk berjualan sate. Saat ini usaha jual satenya cukup berkembang, tetapi dia ingin memperbesar lagi. Oleh karena itu dia ingin mengajukan pinjaman modal usaha kepada KIVA melalui DINARI. Dia berharap dari pinjaman ini dia bisa memiliki rumah sendiri suatu saat nanti.
texts.en:
Markayan is a satay seller who lives in Denpasar, Bali. He is 45 years old and he lives in a rented house with his wife and children is a housing complex Dalung Permai. He sells his satays in the front yard of his rented house.

His satay business is doing quite good, however he needs capital if he wants to expand his business. Therefore he is applying for a loan from Dinari foundation. He is hoping he can grow his business so he can save enough money to buy his own house.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to add working capital

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey C. is 40 years old, married, and has five children. Four of them attend secondary school, and one is married and lives away from home. Her husband, Chay Sokkom, is 35 years old and drives a motorcycle taxi.

Mrs. C. makes a living by selling chicken in the Pursat Market. She purchases chickens from a wholesale breeder that kills and plucks them, which she then sells at retail. Mrs. C. has applied for a loan to purchase additional chickens to resell and to purchase wood to fix up her house. The family resides in Svay Art Commune in the Pursat Province.

loans.use: Buy additional chickens to resell

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
Mrs. Yi Y., 35, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She catches fish and makes fishing tools, earning $5 a day. Her husband, Yi Seng, makes $1 a day as a rice farmer. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have caused a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Yi Seng included.

Mrs. Yi Y. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike and fish. They will use the bike to transport fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to bring fish to market to sell.

loans.name: Nhoem

texts.en:
Nhoem S. is 42, married, and has five children. Two children are in school, two daughters are employed as garment workers at Phnom Penh City, and one son helps with the family business. She and her family live in Kompong Tom Province.

She owns farmland where she and her husband, Kem Khoeun (42), grow rice and vegetables. (She and her husband are pictured on their farmland.)

S. is requesting a loan to help her buy more fertilizer and gasoline for her farm.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Mrs. Lun S., 37, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Kampong Cham province. The children both work in a garment factory.  Lun S. runs a small beauty salon in the village to earn a living and is able to make $1.50 a day. Her shop arranges clothes and make-up for brides and grooms. Her husband is a construction worker building houses. On average, he makes $5 a day.

Mrs. Lun S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase more cosmetic products and clothes for her salon.  (Lun S. is in the picture with her husband and her daughter.)

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic products and clothes.

loans.name: Chhae

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhae N., 25, is married and lives with her husband and young child in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur who has a business grinding rice crops. She has a big mill and is able to make $10 a day. Her father ran the machine before he retired.  

Mrs. Chhae N. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase a big grinding mill to rent to the farmers in the village.

loans.use: To purchase a big grinding mill.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov K., 62, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She has three children, all of whom live and work in Phnom Penh as massage girls. 

Mrs. Pov K. and her husband, Pich Pouk, 64, are rice farmers. Together they earn one dollar a day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has been out of control. These factors have caused a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Pov K. included.

Mrs. Pov K. is asking for a loan of $700 to invest with her children. She will give this money to her children to rent a massage salon in Phnom Penh. She believes that this will help raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To open a massage salon.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chem S., 40, is married and lives with her husband and their two school-aged children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store, making about $5 a day, while her husband is a tailor.

Mrs. Chem S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to add items to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To add to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., 33, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3 each day. Her husband works as a teacher and makes about US$1.50 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also contributed to making the price of rice very high. Keo S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to add items to her grocery’s inventory. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To add items to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Dok's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan for three borrowers. They all live in Ratanak Commune in Battambang Province.

The leader, Mrs. Dok S. O. is 37, married, and has five children. Four of her children are students, and one son is an English Teacher. Her husband, Keo Van Own, 44, is in the Cambodia Military and receives a salary of $35 a month. Mrs. Dok S. O. owns and runs a small store where she sells various kinds of groceries, like cooking ingredients and cakes for kids that live in her village. S. O. is requesting a loan to purchase additional groceries for sale in hopes of expanding her business.

The two other borrowers are Mrs. Meak S., 26, and Mrs. Kim Y., 57, who is a widow. Mrs. Meak S. makes a living selling grilled bananas. She is requesting a loan to pay for house repairs. Mrs. Kim Y. sells fish in the market. To earn extra income, Y. is requesting a loan to purchase soft drinks to resell.

loans.use: Buy additional groceries for sale

loans.name: Yan's Group

texts.en:
Three borrowers are requesting this loan. They all live in Ratanak Commune in Battambang Province.

First borrower: Mrs. Yan P. is 40, married, and has five children. Two sons are construction workers, and one is married and lives far from home. Her husband, Soun Pouv, is a house builder that specializes in wood buildings. Mrs. P. makes and sells nets, which are the main source of income for the familly. She earns approximately $2 per day. Mrs. P. has applied for a loan to purchase raw materials to make additional nets for sale.

Second borrower: Chan S. is 33 and buys recyclables from stores and then resells them for a profit. She has requested a loan to expand her business.

Third borrower: Ly M. is 54 and sells ice. She has requested a loan to buy more ice to resell.

loans.use: Buy raw materials to make nets for sale

loans.name: Noor Muhammad

texts.en:
Noor Muhammad B. is 27 and the father of four children and he lives in Behsood Beland Ghar Jalalabad. He works in agriculture and he has been involved in this field for more than 10 years. He used to be able to support his family well but things are not very good. He is faced with lots of economic difficulties in his family, so he wants to expand his business.

He needs money to expand his business to help his family. He wants to take out an individual loan to complete his seed stock and ready all his land for cultivation, to work hard and make a better income to support his family.

He is happy about this loan. He would like to thank Kiva and the lenders that make this opportunity possible in this poor country where people are faced with lots of problems. He hopes to be successful in his business in the future.

loans.use: buying seeds and preparing his land

loans.name: Imraan

texts.en:
Imraan K. is responsible for his father and mother as well as his own family. He is single. He is busy in agriculture. He learned this business from his father but his father is unable to work in agriculture now. Imraan works hard at growing his crops and he has plenty of land for cultivation but he is unable to make use of it all.

So Imraan wants to take out an individual loan of 40,000 (AF) with a term of 26 months to complete his stock and buy more seeds to plant all his land and get ready for next year's cultivation. This is the season to prepare the lands for cultivation next year. He wants to make better life for his family in the future.

So Imraan is very happy that, with this loan, he can further his business and help his family in the future. His father and all his family want to thank those who help people by making Kiva loans.

loans.use: to complete his seed stock

loans.name: Sar

texts.en:
Sar K., 53, lives in a rural area of Pursat Province, where she farms for a living. Mrs. K. is married and has six children, all of whom live away from home. Her husband, Em Kon, 67, helps work the farm. (They are both shown in the picture.)

She grows rice or vegetable crops, which are the main source of income for the family. She sells her crops 3 or 4 months after planting.

Mrs. K. is applying for a loan to purchase two oxen to help her plow the farm. The loan will help alleviate the hard labor of farming and provide the family with additional fixed assets.

loans.use: Purchase two oxen for farming

loans.name: Segara Mandala Group

texts.id:
Kelompok ”Segara Mandala” yang terdiri dari ibu-ibu yang terletak di Desa Tukadaya merasa sangat senang sekali setelah  menikmati hasil dari pinjaman yang pertama yang dipergunakan untuk modal pemeliharaan babi karena mereka sudah mendapatkan keuntungan walaupun baru sedikit antara Rp 550 000,- Sampai Rp 750 000,- per 6 bulan sekali.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
Dengan keuntungan yang sedikit tersebut anggota kelompok tidak merasa kecewa,tetapi mereka tetap semangat untuk berusaha. Sehingga mereka akan melanjutkan permohonan pinjaman yang kedua yang nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk membeli bibit babi dan pakan babi dan janka waktu pinjaman selama 6 bulan serta pengembaliannya dilakukan akhir periode pinjaman. Dengan tetap melanjutkan usaha dalam beternak babi anggota kelompok Segara Mandala merasa optimis dalam peningkatan keuntungan  karena mereka akan lebih mandiri dalam pemeliharaan ternak.Dengan pengharapan seperti ini maka anggota kelompok                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Segara Mandala berharap keuntungan akan terus meningkat sehingga mereka dapat menunjang perekonomian keluarganya lebih-lebih dalam melanjutkan pendidikan anaknya kejenjang yang lebih tinggi.
texts.en:
"Segara Mandala" group is a group of house wives in Tukadaya village. This group has already succeeded with their 1st loan which they used to raising pigs. They are earning a profit of IDR 550 thousand to IDR 750 thousand per 6 month period (around USD 50 - USD 70/ 6 month period).

Even though the profit is not high they are not discouraged. They are even planning to take the 2nd loan from Dinari foundation. They are planning to use the loan money to buy more piglets to be raised and also to buy pig's food. The loan period will be 6 month where they can repay the loan at the end of the loan period.

They are hoping to be able to expand the business so they can get more profit. WIth this they can improve their lives and also able to send their children to schools.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs and pig foods

loans.name: Do Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Đỗ Thị Trọng năm nay 32 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay 3.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gà. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi khoảng 1000 con gà thịt và gà đẻ trứng  cho thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn  tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để mua cám, thức ăn phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
Mrs. Đỗ Thị Trọng is 32 years old. She has been participating in the TYM Fund since 2007. Her first loan was for 3,000,000 VND which she invested into raising chicken. Today, her family is raising about 1,000 meat-producing chicken and egg-laying hens which produce an income of 5,000,000 VND per month. For this loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND to purchase bran, as feed for the chicken.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising chicken.

loans.name: Chhoem

texts.en:
Chhoem M., a resident of Pursat Province, is 44 years old, married, and has eight children. All of her children are single; one son is employed and three are in school. She is married to Uy Sokha, 49, who drives a motorcycle taxi.

Chhoem M. has been farming for about ten years. She grows rice, vegetables, and fruit trees to provide for her family. Mrs. M. is requesting a loan to purchase oxen to help alleviate the hard work of farming.

loans.use: Purchase oxen for farming

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Đào năm nay 55 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và ba con đã trưởng thành tại xã Tân Hưng huyện Sóc Sơn Hà Nội. Năm 1996 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư mua lưới đánh cá. Từ năm 2003 đến nay gia đình chị đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi phát triển kinh tế gia đình.  Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị Đào đang chăn nuôi  lợn nái, lợn thịt tại nhà, các con chị cũng đều có công việc làm ổn định. Với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng  kinh tế gia đình chị Đào đang ngày càng ổn định hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn đựoc vay 10.000.000đ để mua thêm lợn giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Đào, 55 years old, lives with her husband and three grown children in Tân Hưng commune, Sóc Sơn district, Hà Nội. In 1996, she became a member of the TYM Fund and borrowed money to buy fishing nets. Since 2003, she and her family have invested capital in raising animals to improve their financial situation. Today, Mrs. Đào and her husband raise both sows and porkers (pigs raised for meat) by their house, and their children all have steady employment. The total family income is now about 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month and the financial situation of the family is steadily becoming more secure. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (600 USD) to purchase more breeding pigs and animal feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị K.  năm nay 32 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 2 con đang tuổi đến trường. Năm 1996 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Đến năm 2002 gia đình chị đã đầu tư vốn để đấu thầu ao của hợp tác xã và chăn nuôi theo mô hình trang trại. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang chăn nuôi 400 con vịt đẻ, 2 đàn lợn nái và 1 ao cá cho thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để  mua thức ăn phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị K., 32 years old, has two children who attend school. She became a member of the TYM Fund in 1996, borrowing money to invest in raising pigs. In 2002, she and her family used a loan to run a model fish farm in a pond belonging to the local co-operative. Today, her family has 400 laying ducks, two groups of sows, and one fish pond, which together provide an income of about 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (600 USD) to buy feed for her animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs, ducks, and fish.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Tân  năm nay 49 tuổi. Hiện tại chị đang sống cùng chồng là cán bộ hưư trí và hai con đang đi học. Chị Tân tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, buôn bán hàng tạp hoá. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị hiện nay.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thức ăn chăn nuôi và đầu  tư thêm vốn cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Tân, 49 years old, lives with her retired husband and their two children who attend school. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2005, borrowing money to invest in raising animals and to run a small grocery shop. These enterprises are now the main sources of income for her family. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (900 USD) to buy feed for her animals and to invest in her family’s grocery shop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her grocery shop and feed for animals

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị A. năm nay 32 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1997. Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị đang làm nghề đan lưới tại gia đình. Bên cạnh đó gia đình chị còn có một cửa hàng nhỏ kinh doA. hàng tạp hoá. Với mức thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng cuộc sống của gia đình chị A. đang ngày càng được cải thiện hơn, hai con của chị cũng được đầu tư cho ăn học đầy đủ hơn.
Với mức vốn  10.000.000 mong muốn được vay trong vòng vốn tới, chị A. dự định sẽ sử dụng để đầu tư thêm vốn cho công việc kinh doA. của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi A. is 32 years old. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 1997. Today, she and her husband work from home making nets. They also have a small storefront selling general goods. With an income of 5,000,000 VND per month, her family's lifestyle continues to improve each day. And they can put money towards giving her children a more complete education. With the 10,000,000 VND she hopes to borrow in this loan cycle, Mrs.A. is planning to use it to invest more into the family's retail business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in family's retail business

loans.name: Dong Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Đông năm nay 49 tuổi,chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1996. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Với việc chăn nuôi 20 con lợn nái, 150 con gà đẻ và nuôi cá thu nhập của gia đình chị Đông hàng tháng đạt 3.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thức ăn phục vụ cho việc chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Dong Thi N. is a 49 years old woman. She joined the TYM fund in 1996. Now the family’s income comes mainly from their farm. The farm of fish, 20 breeding pigs, and 150 hens brings in the income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy food supply.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food supply

loans.name: Lich Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Lịch tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1997. Trong hơn 10 năm  vay vốn của Quỹ tình thương gia đình chị đều sử dụng vốn để đi thu mua phế liệu. Hiện tại đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị .Bên cạnh đó hàng tháng gia đình chị đều có thêm sự hỗ trợ của các con đã đi làm nên kinh tế gia đình rất ổn định.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để tiếp tục đầu tư vốn đi thu mua phế liệu.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lich Thi N. joined the TYM fund in 1997. For 10 years, she has been using loans to run her business. She buys junks from people and then sells it back to factories. At the moment, the family’s income comes mainly from this business. She also receives supports from her children, who are working; therefore, the family financial situation is stable. She plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more  scrap

loans.name: Duongchan

texts.en:
Duongchan S. is 55, married, and has five children. Three of his children are employed: one son is a hair cutter in Phnom Penh City, and two daughters are dealers in a casino. His wife, Soeum Tep, 44, helps him with his business. He and his family reside in Pursat Province.

Duongchan S. sells ice cream to his community from the back of his motorcycle. His best customers are young students in school. He earns approximately $5 per day. S. has applied for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one.

loans.use: Purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Huong Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Bùi Thị Hường năm nay 44 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003. Hiện nay công việc đem lại thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi và buôn bán giò chả. Với mức thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Hường đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000 đ để đầu tư mua thực phẩm phục vụ cho việc sản xuất kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Huong Thi B. is a 44 years old woman. She joined the TYM fund in 2003. At the moment, she is raising livestock and making grilled chopped meat for living. These businesses bring in 2,500,000 Vietnamese Dong and gradually improve the family’s financial situation. Mrs. B. plans to make the next loan of 15,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to buy food supply for the businesses.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food supply

loans.name: Ai Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Ái năm nay 52 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại Xã Nghi Trung huyện Nghi Lộc tỉnh Nghệ An. Chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Hiện tại chồng chị và các con đang làm ruộng và chăn nuôi tại gia đình còn chị đi chợ buôn bán rau. Với mức thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng  kinh tế gia đình chị đang ngày càng ổn định hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc buôn bán của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ai Thi N., 52 years old, is living with her husband and two children in Nghi Trung, Nghi Loc, Nghe An. She has been the TYM fund's partner since 2004. At the moment, her husband and her children work on the family’s field and raise livestock, while she sells vegetable in local market. With income of 2,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month, they are gradually improving the family’s financial situation. She plans to make the next loan of 9,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Neti

texts.en:
Neti is 35 years old and married with a child. She and her family live in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells groceriers, such as noodles, milk, sugar, and tomato paste.  

Neti is a LAPO client. She is hoping for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more grocers to sell. She says thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Anh Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Anh năm nay 35 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 2 con còn nhỏ. Năm 2004 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán nhỏ . Hiện tại chị đang bán đồ ăn sáng tại chợ phục vụ cho nhu cầu của người dân địa phương. Với mức thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị hiện nay. Bên cạnh đó gia đình chị còn kết hợp chăn nuôi thêm nên thu nhập của gia đình khá ổn định. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn phục vụ cho công việc buôn bán của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Anh Thi N. is a 35 years old woman. Her family has two small children. In 2004, she joined the TYM fund, borrowing money to start a small business. She has a small food booth in the local market, serving breakfast. Income of 2,500,000 Vietnamese Dong per month from this business is the family’s main source of income. Besides, her family is also raising livestock. Therefore, the family’s financial situation is stable. She plans to make the next loan of 10,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Taing

texts.en:
Taing R. is 26 years old, married, and has two children. Both of her children are young and go to primary school. Her husband, Bin Say, 29, is a fisherman. She and her family live in Kompong Tom Province.

She is a local farmer who specializes in growing both rice and vegetables. She has been widely known in the business for over seven years, earning approximately $1.50 per day. R. is requesting a loan to purchase two cows to help her with the farming.

loans.use: Purchase two cows

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Vân năm nay 40 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị là chăn nuôi và sản xuất bún. Với sự hỗ trợ của chồng và hai con đã trưởng thành  công việc chăn nuôi, sản xuất của gia đình chị đang phát triển rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
 Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua gạo dự trữ phục vụ cho việc sản xuất bún tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi V. is 40 years old. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2004. Currently, raising livestock and making vermicelli bring the main part of her family's income. With the support of her husband and two children who are grown up, her business is growing well and brings an income of VND3,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow VND15,000,000 to buy rice to stock up for the vermicelli making business to increase income for her family.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice to make vermicelli

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Trần Thị H. năm nay 50 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 4 con trong đó 3 con đã trưởng thành. Năm 2004 chị H. tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá. Công việc kinh doanh đang phát triển thuận lợi cho thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Hiện nay đây là công việc đem lại thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị H..
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn phục vụ cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tran Thi H. is 50 years old. She has four children and three of them are grown up. In 2004 Mrs. H. joined the TYM Fund and borrowed money to invest in a general store. The business is going well and produces a monthly income of VND3,000,000. This business is the main source of income for Mrs. H.'s family. In this loan cycle, Mrs. H. would like to borrow VND15,000,000 to invest to expand her general store business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in the general store

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is married and has two grown children. She sells various home products at the central market in Berdyansk, and she has a very good selling location with a good flow of customer traffic.. Her monthly gross income is 4,000 UAH, the profit is about 2,000 UAH (about $253).

Alla works with her daughter in her business, and they are both known as hard-working, responsible business women. They know their customers and what they like, and this helps them keep old customers and attract new ones. Alla is requesting a loan so she can purchase new inventory. She will use her increased earnings to repair her house and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Sak's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan being requested by three borrowers. The borrowers reside in Chomkasomrong Commune in Battambang Province.

The leader, Mrs. Sak T., 39, is a teacher. She has five children: one is married, two are employed, and the remainder are students. She teaches students in Metapheap Primary School, and gets a salary of $100 per month. She is married to SE. Nak, 46, who makes a living driving a motorcycle taxi. He leaves the house early in the morning to provide this service to his customers. Mrs. T. has requested a loan to buy a motorcycle to provide for her family's transportation.

The other two borrowers who are requesting this loan are Mrs. Sok K. who is 40 and Mrs. Chuom E. who is 33. Mrs. Sok K. sells duck eggs in the market and needs a loan so she can order more eggs to resell. Mrs. Chuom E. sells sugar cane juice from a cart. Mrs. E. is requesting a loan for her husband to replace his old motorcycle.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Kaniz M.sharif Group

texts.en:
Kaniz baji is a 58 year old lady and resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  Pakpattan city is famous for its saint places.  Most people come to this city to visit the saint places for making wishes.  

Kaniz baji is an uneducated woman, but she knows the value of education and knowledge.  She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter.  Her elder son completed his education up until the 8th standard, and started his own work of selling fruit salad.  The next son to him is completing his 10th standard.  Her youngest son is in kindergarten, and her daughter reads in the 5th standard.  Kaniz baji’s husband’s name is M. who is a tailor by profession.  

She wants to see her children well settled.  For this purpose she does embroidery on dresses and sells in cloth shops.  She works day and night to complete one dress.  She sells each embroidered dress for $3.  

She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy another sewing machine to expand her husband’s tailoring business. 

She is a group leader of a few more members from her locality.  Sheema baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy wheat and rice to resell.  Azra baji wants a loan to buy furniture (chairs and a mirror) for her salon.  Tasleem baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture making business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Rubina Aziz M.shafiq Group

texts.en:
Rubina aziz baji is a 29 year old lady and resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places.  Most people come to this city to visit the shrine places to make wishes. 

Rubina baji owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the past 5 years.  She is the mother of eight children: six daughters and two sons.  None of her children go to school.  Her husband is a fruit seller by profession, and has 4 years of experience.  

Rubina baji herself has a decorative embroidery business.  She also teaches the girls in her community how to embroider dresses.  She has been making embroidered dresses for the past 4 years.  She does this work to support her husband in meeting the financial expenses of the house.  

She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her husband’s fruit selling business. 
 
She is a group leader of a few more members of her community.  Sakina baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business.  Razia baji wants a loan to buy tools for her jewelry making business.  Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Kaniz Fatima baji wants a loan to buy stamp papers to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji E. is currently in the business of making bread and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Keji is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a secretary. She has three children and they all go to school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her bread-making business in order to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Née en 1974 à Kpalimé, Mademoiselle D. Akua est une revendeuse adulée résident à Aného. Célibataire avec deux (02) enfants, elle fait le stockage et la vente de charbons de bois, des céréales et de la farine du manioc. Avec les difficultés socio économique qui prévaut dans le milieu, les revenus de son commerce ne couvrent plus les charges qui ne cessent d’augmenter malgré de multiples efforts consentis.
Dans le souci de réduire sa misère et celle de ses enfants, elle sollicite un financement pour augmenter son fond de commerce afin de stocker du charbon et les céréales en grande quantité. Ces stocks qu’elle revendra chers en période de pénurie afin de réaliser un profit maximum.
texts.en:
Miss Akua D. was born in Kpalimé in 1974 and is a respected retailer in Aného. Single with two children, she stores and sells charcoal, cereals and manioc flour. Due to prevailing social and economic problems, her profits no longer cover costs which continue to increase despite concerted efforts to prevent this. In an attempt to reduce the risk of poverty to herself and her children, she seeks a loan to increase her business capital in order to stock large quantities of charcoal and cereals. She will resell these stocks at a high price in periods of shortage to gain maximum profit.

Translated from French by Holly Miller, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stocking and selling of charcoal and cereals

loans.name: Umija

texts.en:
Ujima, a single 22-year-old, is currently in the business of selling food at a hotel and is requesting a loan to expand the business. With the extra profits accruing from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a perminent house for rent

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice K. is currently in the business of baking bread and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Alice is 28 years old and married. Her husband is an accountant. She has five children, who all attend school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her bakery in order to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Magret

texts.en:
Magret, 28 years old and married to an engineer, has two children attending school. She is currently in the business of brewing local alcohol and is requesting a loan to expand the business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children through expansion of her business.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua A. is a trader in Iture near Elmina. She sells products such as oil and also prepares kenkey (maize dumplings) for sale. She has been doing this since 1994. Ekua is married and has three children. Her husband is an electrician, while Ekua has received no formal education.

Ekua will use the money from her loan to buy more goods for sale at the market and to purchase more maize for the preparation of the kenkey. She will use the profits to feed her children, pay their school fees and pay other bills. She will use the rest to support her business.

In the yellow containers in the photo are some samples of the oil she sells.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and buy more maize for kenkey preparation.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia S. sells tomatoes in the market and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Lucia is 32 years old and married. Her husband is a policeman. She has six children, who all attend school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to send the children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Sim's Group

texts.en:
There are three borrowers requesting this loan. They all live in Chomkasomroang Commune in Battambang Province.

The leader, Mrs. Sim S., 49, is widowed. She is a teacher, as well as a tailor, who works for an orphanage. She receives a salary of a $120 per month. Sometimes she earns additional income by sewing clothes for her neighbors in her house. She lives with two of her children, both of whom are single. Her first daughter works in a hotel; the other daughter is a student. S. has applied for a loan to purchase sewing materials and cloth for her tailoring business.

The two other borrowers are Mrs. Chan S. who is 58 and a widow, and Mrs. Yeam S. who is 31 and divorced. Mrs. Chan S. sells groceries and is requesting a loan to buy additional groceries for resale. Mrs. Yeam S. sells brooms for income and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials and cloth

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity C. sells beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Charity is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a security guard. She has three children, who all attend school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: Née le 04 janvier 1968 à Kovié, Madame N. Adjovi est couturière de métier et est surtout très active dans le commerce de pagnes. Ce commerce lui procure plus de bénéfice. Soutenue financièrement, Madame N. à régulièrement remboursé et soldé à temps ses crédits. Ce qui lui a permets aujourd’hui d'accroitre ses activités. Face aux demandes sans cesse croissante de sa clientèle, elle sollicite un nouveau financement. Ce financement accordé lui permettra d’accroître son chiffre d'affaires et ses profits.
texts.en:
Adjovi N. was born on 4 January 1968 in Kovié and is a seamstress who works principally in the pagnes trade. This business secures her greater profits. Financially secure, Mrs N. has regularly repaid and settled her debts on time, which has now given her the opportunity to increase her business activities. Due to the ever increasing demands of her clientele, she is seeking a new loan. This loan will allow her to augment her turnover and profits.

Translated from French by Holly Miller, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pagnes trade

loans.name: Zinaubu

texts.en: Sinabu   is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Sinabu is 35 years old and is married with a husband that is a builder. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send the children to school.
