BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: selling charcoal

loans.name: Ludia

texts.en:
Ludia S. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Ludia is 20 years old and married. Her husband is a security guard. She has three children, who all attend school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay for her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Nestor Lonlonyo

texts.fr: Né en 1963 à Gapé-Nyassivé, Monsieur A. Lonlonyo Nestor est marié et père de cinq (05) enfants. Gérant d’un dépôt de ciment, il a réussi a relancer son activité grâce aux micro crédits qu’il n’a jamais regrettés. Aujourd’hui, il n’a plus de problème de rupture de stock. Mais pour renforcer son activité en s’approvisionnant dans l’usine même de fabrication, il sollicite encore un financement plus important. Ce financement lui permettra de faire face aux fortes demandes de la part de ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Gapé-Nyassivé, Mr. Lonlonyo Nestor A. is married and the father of five. Managing a cement outlet, he succeeded in reinvigorating his business, thanks to the micro-loans that he never regretted. Today, he no longer has problems with inventory shortages. But to bolster his business by getting supplies for the factory itself, he is requesting more sizable financing, which will enable him to address the strong demand from his customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in cement

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sun N. is 54, married, and has four children. Two of her children are married; the two single children work as construction workers to help support the family. Her husband is a rice farmer.

Mrs. Sun N. grows vegetables and sells fish, which she purchases from fishermen and then resells at the market for profit. Rice farming is the main income for the family. She and her husband work very hard everyday to pay the family's daily expenses. Mrs. N. is requesting a loan to purchase two oxen, which she hopes will improve her crops and alleviate the hard work of farming.

loans.use: Purchase two oxen for farming

loans.name: Naz Begum M.umar Group

texts.en:
Naz Begum resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places.  Most people come to this city to visit the shrine places and make wishes.  She has been living in this city for the past 30 years.  Her husband's name is M., and he is a barber by profession who runs a salon in the community.  He has 4 years of experience in this business.  

Naz Baji has four children: two sons and two daughters.  All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.  Naz Baji is a seamstress and she sews clothes for her neighbors.  She has been in this business for the past 15 years.  She does this work to bear the expenses of her children’s education, and her husband bears the house expenses.  She is applying for a loan to buy a hair dressing machine for her husband’s salon. 

She is a group leader of a few more ladies in her community.  Fozia Baji and Irshad Baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.  Ghulam Fatima Baji wants a loan to buy wheat and rice to resell.  Irshad Baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a hair dressing machine for a barber salon

loans.name: Kayi

texts.fr:
Née en 1972 à Zowla, Madame Z. Kayi exerce le métier de coiffure depuis 10 ans. Elle est mariée et a cinq enfants. Elle est une femme dynamique, très dévouée et maîtrise bien son activité. Son mari n’ayant pas un revenu fixe, les charges de la famille reviennent seule. Toutefois, le revenu tiré de son métier ne lui permet pas de couvrir tous ces besoins. 
Pour renforcer son activité et accroître son revenu, elle sollicite un financement pour faire le commerce des mèches et autres produits de beauté.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Zowla, Ms. Kayi Z. has been a hairdresser by trade for ten years. She is married and has five children. She is an energetic and very devoted woman who has a good command of her work. Because her husband lacks a steady income, the family expenses fall entire upon her shoulders. In any case, the income derived from her work doesn’t allow her to cover all these needs. To bolster her business and to grow her income, she is requesting financing to do commerce in hair extensions and other beauty products.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell hair extensions and beauty products in her hair salon

loans.name: Natalia

texts.en: Natalia is divorced and has one grown son. She sells jeans wear at two markets in Berdiansk. Her monthly gross income is 5,000 UAH, her net  profit is about 2,500 UAH (about $316). Nataliya works hard, treats her customers well, and sells products that people want to buy. That is why she's been able to operate in two markets. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase winter jeans and winter wear so she can keep developing her business and offering her clients more good clothing. This will help stablize her income further and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Mumtaz M.shahbaz Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz Baji resides in a city of shrines named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  She owns a two-room brick house in this city and has been living in it for the past 30 years.  Her husband's name is M., and he runs a tea stall.  He has 4 years of experience in this business.  He is a very devoted and hardworking person. 

Mumtaz Baji has been involved in a clothes selling business for the past 4 years.  She buys clothes from a famous city named Multan and resells in her own city to earn a profit.  

She is the mother of two daughters.  Her elder daughter reads in the 7th standard, and her younger daughter reads in kindergarten.  Mumtaz Baji and her husband work really hard for their daughter’s good future.  She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her clothes selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few more women in her community.  Musarat Shaheen Baji and Zahida Parveen Baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Sharifan Baji wants a loan to buy materials (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business.  Shahana Basher Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business.  Parveen A. Baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Née en 1971 à Kpogan, Madame A. Akossiwa est nantie d’un diplôme de coiffure et l’exerce depuis 05 ans. Mariée, elle est mère de deux (02) enfants. Intelligente, sincère et aimant le travail bien fait, elle séduit sa clientèle par la qualité de sa prestation.
Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle toujours en croissance, elle sollicite un financement pour initier la vente de produits cosmétiques et acheter d’autres appareils séchoirs plus performants. Ceci lui permettra d’accroître son revenu et d’assurer son autonomie financière.
texts.en:
Born in 1971 in Kpogan, Ms. Akossiwa A. is lucky to have a hairdresser’s diploma and has been styling hair for five years. Married and the mother of two, she is an intelligent and sincere women who likes a job well-done. She wins over her customers through the quality of her service. To better satisfy her every-growing customer base, she is requesting financing to get started in selling cosmetics and to buy other better-performing hair dryers. This will enable her to grow her income and to ensure her financial autonomy.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair dryers and to sell cosmetics

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi I. is a trader. She sells kenkey (maize dumplings) and gari (cassava that has been grated, fermented and roasted) at Atrankwa near Elmina, which she has been doing since 1997.

Esi is divorced and has five dependents. She has received no formal education.

Esi will use the money from her loan to buy more cassava and maize for the preparation of the gari and kenkey. She will use the profits to feed her children and to save towards building a house.

In the photo she is demonstrating how the kenkey is prepared.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and maize for the preparation of gari and kenkey.

loans.name: Rashida Begum Hassan Raza Group

texts.en:
Rashida Begum is a 30 year old lady and resides in a shrine city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  She has been living in this city for the past 30 years.  Rashida Baji completed her education up until the 8th standard, but couldn’t study further because of her family’s poor conditions.  

Her husband's name is H. R., and he is a driver by profession.  He drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle), and has 5 years of experience in this business.  Rashida Baji has no children.  She spends her time sewing clothes.  This activity enables her to earn 1500 Pak Rupees per month.  

She is applying for a loan to change the body of her husband’s auto-rickshaw. 

Rashida Baji is a group leader of a few more members of her community.  Zareena Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business.  Sugran Baji and Razia Parveen Baji each want a loan to buy plastic utensils to resell.  Kursheeda Baji wants a loan to buy a grinding machine for grinding flour.  Qureshan Baji wants a loan to buy tools for her motor workshop. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To change the body of an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua P. is a trader. She sells kenkey - maize dumplings - one of the most popular foods eaten among all the tribes in the country. She does her business at Atrankwa near Elmina and she has been doing this since 1994. She has not received any formal education. She is a widow with two children.

Ekua will use the money from her loan to buy more maize to make kenkey. She plans to use the profits to feed her children and to support her business.

In the basket are some samples of the type of kenkey she sells.

loans.use: To buy more maize to make kenkey for sale.

loans.name: Fazrat

texts.en:
Fazrat M. is a 26-year-old man who breeds calves in a small village in Saatli region. Fazarat is young but full of energy; he tries every single day to make the life of his parents better. Fazrat started his business in 2002. He continued the business of his father, who is a pensioner. Fazrat has great experience in cattle breeding because he observed it from his childhood. He got an education in finance/economics he works in local organization as an accountant so that he doesn't lose his skills, but his main financial income comes from cattle selling.

Fazrat would like to expand his business and purchase more calves. This will help him to increase income and improve life conditions. Fazrat is planning to get married next year. We wish his good luck and appreciate for your help!

loans.use: Purchase four calves

loans.name: Sope Khadim Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Sope Khadim  faisant parti de l'écovillage Thiaroye compte lutter contre l'oisiveté et prendre en charge leur propre destinée. C’est pourquoi les femmes se sont organisées en groupement et préfèrent s’activer pour la promotion socio-économique de ses membres tout en participent au développement de leur communauté. Ce prêt a pour objectif de renforcer l’activité de transformation de céréale locale dont elles maitrisent déjà. L'activité tourne autour de l’achat de céréales locales (mil, maïs, sorgho) et après procéder à leur transformation. La vente de ces produits transformés d’où le « thiacri, araw » (noms sénégalais des produits)  permettra de rembourser le prêt sans grande difficulté. L’écoulement des produits ne posant aucun problème car l’offre étant inférieure à la demande, ce prêt permettra donc d’améliorer l’offre au plan qualitatif et quantitatif.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sope Khadim, being part of the eco-village Thiaroye, intend to fight against idleness and to take charge of their own destiny. This is why the women got organized into a group. They prefer to be active in the socio-economic advancement of all its members by participating in the development of their community.

The objective of this loan is to bolster their business of processing local grain. This is work they've already mastered, and it is centered on purchasing local grain (millet, corn, sorghum) and then proceeding to process it. The sale of the resulting products "thiacri" and "araw" (the Senegalese names) will allow the loan to be repaid without much difficulty. The turnover of these products pose no problem because the quantity to be sold is less than the level of demand. This loan will allow them to improve the quality and quantity of the goods to be sold.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials to process into cereal products

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aslon

texts.en:
Aslon A. is 27 years old. He is married with 3 adorable children. Aslon has always opted to make his life in his homeland, to work hard and grow with it. That is how he decided to rear sheep and dedicate himself to agriculture. He has been doing this kind of work for a very long time, as he comes from a family with an entirely agricultural background. Today he wishes to increase the number of his animals with the hope of increasing his income and improving the well-being of his home with the innumerable benefits that these special little animals provide him. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1,200) for the term of 12 months. Your solidarity will help Aslon move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

loans.use: Purchasing sheep for improving his living conditions

loans.name: Imran

texts.en:
Imran I. is a 39-year-old trader who sells different kinds of food and cigarettes. Imran started his business in 1993, in very hard times of the country and for himself, when he fled to Bilasuvar, an Internally Displaced People Settlement during the Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict.

Unemployment pushed him to start selling different kind of goods. He started to sell eggs and step-by-step he expanded his business and now he rents a place. He is married and has a daughter. Imran`s dream is to build his own store and provide for his daughter's education. For this purpose he applied for 1200 USD. He will use the loan to purchase more foodstuffs.

loans.use: Purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Zahida Parveen M.nazir Group

texts.en:
Zahida Parveen Baji resides in a shrine city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  She owns a two-room brick house in this holy city, and has been living in it for the past 20 years.  

She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters.  All of her children are getting an education in a local school.  Her husband's name is M., and he runs a grocery shop in the community.  He has a good reputation with people.  Most of the people in the community come to him to buy groceries. 

Zahida Baji is a seamstress and sews clothes for her neighbors, charging $2 per dress.  She invests her income in her children’s education and her husband meets the financial expenses of the house.  She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy more groceries for her husband’s grocery shop. 

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members.  Muniran Baji wants a loan to buy blankets to resell.  Irfana Baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes.  Sabran Baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.  Razia Baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Zarifjon

texts.en:
Zarifjon is 38 years old and lives with his wife and 2 children. Recently he has gotten involved in agriculture, as his parents were farmers in their area and now he wishes to follow in their footsteps. For this reason he is giving his all to his land, where he is busy all day long. The harvest is what gives him the most pleasure from his work, since he can pick the products that cost him so much work in cultivating and caring. Nevertheless, the most difficult thing is acquiring the fertilizers necessary for his plots, since they are very expensive and raise the level of investment required in production. Zarifjon draws strength from his 2 children, whom he supports so that they may become professionals. He wishes to invest in the various fertilizers he needs for his crops, so that he can increase his production and his profits.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Muninu

texts.en:
Muninu B. is a trader. He operates a milling machine used by gari producers to get their cassava milled. He also produces gari for sale at Abrobeano near Elmina. His wife is also a trader and they have seven dependents. He has received no formal education.

Muninu intends to use this loan to buy more cassava so he can increase the amount of gari he makes. He will use the profits from this to pay his children’s school fees, to pay off bills and to feed his family.

The photo shows Muninu standing by one of his milling machines.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and increase his gari production.

loans.name: Fizuli

texts.en:
Fizuli Q. is a 45-year-old trader who has sold fruits and vegetables in his own store since 2000. He is married and has one son. From the income he earned during the last eight years, he was able to build his store last year. His store is located in a place where many people pass during the day.

Fizuli wishes to provide to his son an excellent education, but for this purpose he needs more additional funds to increase the number of goods he sells. For this purpose he applied for 1200 USD. This loan he will use to purchase more fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr:
Madame H. Dédé est née en 1970 à Lomé. Couturière de profession, elle en fait sa principale activité. Mariée avec quatre (04) enfants a charge, elle arrive par son dynamisme à s’occuper des besoins de sa famille par les revenus tirés de son activité. Douée dans la confection des habits, elle exerce son métier avec des moyens matériels dérisoires. 
Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, elle sollicite un financement afin d'aménager convenablement un atelier et s’acheter des machines à coudre. Cela lui permettra de satisfaire dans les délais ses clients et aussi améliorer ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Ms. Dédé H. was born in 1970 in Lomé. A dressmaker by profession, she has made it her principal line of work. Married and having four children to look after, she manages to take care of her family’s need through her dynamism and the income derived from her business. Though a talented maker of clothing, she practices her trade with pitiful equipment. To satisfy her customers better, she is requesting financing to fix up a workshop appropriately and to buy sewing machines. This will enable her to satisfy her customers on time and also to improve her living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up a workshop and to buy sewing machines

loans.name: Matluba

texts.en:
Matluba B. works selling shoes from her own stall inside the clothing market in the beautiful town of Istaravshan, Tajikistan. She has spent the last 11 years dedicating herself to this business. The business generates enough income in order to be able to live with dignity. lMON has provided Matluba with financial help for the last year, which has allowed her to increase her stock and ensure her three children’s sustenance. She currently has a pressing need to acquire more shoes for the winter season in order to market them, and for this reason she came to IMON looking for more support. Her goal is to continue expanding and improving her business every day, considering that her husband's job as a driver does not earn enough and her children have no steady work. So, Matluba has to work hard in order to improve their living conditions. Matluba is very grateful to everyone who is helping her.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing winter boots for men

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael K. is a trader. He sells nets, lead and other fishing items at Abrobeano near Elmina. He has been doing this since 1998. He attended school through senior high school and is married with four children. His wife is also a trader.

Michael intends to use the money from this loan to increase his inventory. He will use his profits to pay his children’s school fees, feed them and also pay other bills. He will use the rest to expand his business.

loans.use: Michael intends to use the loan to buy more fishing goods for sale.

loans.name: Kaneez Begum M. Murad Group

texts.en:
Kaneez Begum Baji is 34 a year old lady who resides in a shrine city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  She has been living in this city for the past 20 years.  

Her husband's name is M. M., and he has a clothes selling business.  She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters.  Her elder son helps his father in the clothes selling business.  The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.  

Kaneez Baji has a clothes sewing business.  She earns 1500 Pak Rupees per month, which she saves to pay her children’s school fees.  She has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her husband’s clothes selling business. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her community.  Shamim Baji and Naziran Baji each want a loan to buy clothes for their clothes selling business. 
 
This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for selling

loans.name: Gulchira

texts.en:
Gulchira is a hardworking entrepreneur from Istaravshan, a city in the northern part of Tajikistan. She and her husband have three children. She runs a business where she sells kids' shoes at the busy central market in Istaravshan. Gulchira started her business 15 years ago and has run it with both extreme care and seriousness. It is an important source of income for her family of five, considering that her husband is currently unemployed. Gulchira has requested a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600) so that she can purchase additional inventory of winter boots for children and continue developing her business. Thanks to this loan, she will be able to grow her business further and help feed her family. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. loans.use: Purchasing winter boots for kids

loans.name: Valérie

texts.fr:
Née à Aného en 1970, Madame N. Valérie est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Le commerce de denrées de premières nécessités est son activité quotidienne. Elle a ouvert une petite boutique d’alimentation générale qu’elle gère avec soins. C’est grâce à cette activité qu’elle subvient aux besoins de son foyer.
Aujourd’hui, elle sollicite un financement pour approvisionner sa boutique en produits nécessaires afin d’être à la hauteur de la demande de ses clients et de la concurrence. Le revenu de son activité lui permettra de mieux subvenir aux nombreux besoins de sa famille sur le plan sanitaire, scolaire et alimentaire.
texts.en:
Born in Aného in 1970, Ms. Valérie N. is married and the mother of a child. The work she does each day involves commerce in staple items. She opened a small grocery store and manages it with care. Thanks to this business, she is providing for the needs of her household. Today, she is requesting financing to get a supply of beauty products necessary to rise to the demands of her customers and the challenges of her competition. The income from her work enables her to meet numerous family needs with regard to sanitation, schooling, and food.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get merchandise for her store

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en: Elshad H. is a 28-year-old butcher who works in a small butcher shop located along the road, which makes this place very successful. Elshad is married and has 2 sons.  He started his business in 2002 when he decided to separate from his father who was engaged in cattle breeding. His permanent customers are people who pass his shop, restaurant owners and local people. Elshad has applied for 1200 USD to improve the conditions of his working place.

loans.use: improve the conditions of his store

loans.name: Tahira Khadim Hussain Group

texts.en:
Tahira Baji is a 40 year old lady who resides in a city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine places.  People come to visit Pakpattan to make wishes in shrine places.  She believes that she is blessed to be a part of this city. 

Tahira Baji completed her education up until the 10th standard.  She then married a man who is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters.  All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.  

Tahira Baji has a clothes sewing business.  She learned this art from her mother.  She earns worth 1500 Pak Rupees per month, which she uses to pay her children’s school fees.  She is applying for a loan to repair her hsuband’s auto-rickshaw. 

She is a group leader of a few more members of her community.  Sakina Baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell.  Sumera Rani Baji wants a loan to buy spare parts of vehicles to resell.  Maryam Baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw.  Anwar Baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.en:
Vegetable farming is a traditional occupation in northern Tajikistan, especially in Dilafruz’s village. Having a fairly large amount of land surrounding her house, this mother of four decided to try growing vegetables. Neither she nor her husband has been able to find steady employment, and she has been observing the success of her relatives and neighbors who sell vegetables at the market. She has experience growing and selling produce and wants to now do so more intensively to generate more income for her family. She has many ideas about how to be competitive by growing the right crops in a certain way, and she is sure that she will do well. She is requesting a loan to purchase mineral fertilizer and seeds so she can grow her business. Dilafruz sincerely thanks you for your generous heart. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing mineral fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Kamoutène 2 Group

texts.fr:
http://sem-fund.org/carabane.php


Après une première expérience réussie, nous venons solliciter Kiva pour l'octroi d'un deuxième prêt qui va mous permettre de consolider nos activités antérieures ( achat et vente de produits halieutiques transformés dans notre écovillage) et de pouvoir acheter ausi des produits fabriqués dans les villes (ustensiles courantes de cuisines et autres produits cosmétiques et parfumeries) pour les revendre dans notre écovillage et ses environs. Le premier prêt nous a permis de comprendre comment on peut gagner sa vie en travaillant honnêtement et de voir comment faire des économies. Cette fois nous voulons faire en sorte que notre activité qui est la commercialisation des produits divers, soit une activité plus formelle, car avec ce montant, nous auront plus de capacité à répondre à la demande et aussi faire face à l'offre des produits halieutique transformés par nos pècheurs qui s'activent dans notre écovillage. Cela nous permettra de nous soutenir entre nous pour lutter contre la pauvreté qui est très forte dans cette zone enclavée qui est notre île de Carabane
texts.en:
After a successful initial experience, we are here to request from Kiva a second granting of a loan that will enable us consolidate our previous work (buying and selling seafood products produced in our eco-village) and also to buy in cities some manufactured goods (common kitchen utensils, cosmetics, and perfumes) to resell in our eco-village and surrounding areas. The first loan enabled us to understand how to earn a living by working honestly and to see how to save money. This time, we want to see to it that our business, which is the marketing of various products, is more formalized because, with this loan amount, we will have a greater ability to meet the demand and also to handle the seafood products being sold by our fishermen, who are active in our eco-village. This will enable us to support ourselves in the fight against poverty, which is very great in our isolated area, that is, Carabane Island.

http://sem-fund.org/carabane.php

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy utensils and fresh seafood to process

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is divorced and has two teenage daughters. She sells food in a little store at Drogobych city. Maria has been in this business for 5 years. She used to manage a store under the Soviet Union, but when the USSR fell, the employees at that store lost their jobs. Later many of them, like Maria, opened their own small stores and businesses.
Because of her experience, Maria was able to make her small business a success.

Maria would like to get a loan of 5,000 UAH ($632) to purchase more goods for the coming holiday season so she can increase her assortment of inventory. Even though Maria is alone and raises two children herself, she is very optimistic and believes that Jesus Christ can help her to overcome any difficult situation.

loans.use: To increase inventory assortment

loans.name: Shakeela M.ramzan Group

texts.en:
Shakeela Baji is a 42 year old lady who resides in a shrine city named Pakpattan, Pakistan.  She has been living in this city for the past 10 years.  

Her husband's name is M., and he has a tea stall in the community.  He has 6 years of experience in this business.  Shakeela Baji is a mother of eight children: six daughters and two sons.  Her first two daughters sew clothes and earn a profit.  The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. 

Shakeela baji also sews clothes and earns a profit.  She uses her profits to pay her children's school fees.  She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy materials (tea and sugar) for her husband’s tea stall. 

She is a group leader of a few more women.  Azra Bano Baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.  Kosar Baji and Zainab Baji each want a loan to buy blankets to resell.  Sakina Baji and Sheedan Baji each want a loan to buy chairs and mirrors for their salon.  Munawar Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for a tea stall

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca A. is a trader. She sells maize in bags to the kenkey producers; she also makes kenkey (maize dumplings) for sale at Abrobeano near Elmina, which she has been doing since 1990.

Francicsa has received no formal education. She is married with six dependents and her husband is a fisherman.

Francisca intends to use this loan to buy more sacks of maize so she can have enough to prepare her kenkey for resale at the market. She will use the profits to support her children’s education.

We asked Francisca to demonstrate how the kenkey is prepared. The corn dough is mixed with water and then stirred on the fire until it solidifies. It is then taken from the fire and allowed to cool down. More fresh corn dough is mixed with the cooked dough and then wrapped in a corn husk. The wrapped dough is then boiled until it's cooked.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of maize to prepare kenkey for resale at the market.

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr:
Madame A. Améyo est une jeune dame de 32 ans. Mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants, elle réside actuellement à Kpémé.
Le commerce d’alimentation générale est sa principale source de revenus lui permettant de subvenir aux charges de la famille car le revenu de son mari n’arrive pas à couvrir tous les besoins de la famille. 
Pour renforcer son commerce, elle sollicite un financement afin d'approvisionner suffisamment sa boutique en marchandises. Ceci lui permettra d'accroitre son chiffres d'affaires et ses profits.
texts.en:
Améyo A. is a young woman of 32. She is married, has 3 children, and currently lives in Kpémé. Her main source of income is the sale of groceries, which allows her to support her family as her husband's income is not sufficient to pay all of the family's expenses. She is requesting a loan in order to bolster her business: she will buy supplies in order to have a well-stocked store. This will allow her to increase her sales and her profits.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her store with merchandise

loans.name: Latofat

texts.en:
Latofat I. is a strong woman who has not allowed the passage of years to diminish the value of her work, and as such has always set a solid example for many youths of today. She was born in an agricultural family that taught her the hard work of tilling the land and also the joint effort the goes into arduous work. She has been dedicated independently for 7 years to agriculture, sowing corn, potatoes and onions. Latofat’s great wish is to provide for the studies of her four children, and for this reason she works hard. At harvest time she sells directly in the wholesale market of her locality in order to obtain profits. Latofat requests a loan to acquire a greater quantity of fertilizer with the objective of improving the quality of her products. Thank you for supporting Latofat and her desire to work hard and improve her living.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa S. is a trader. She sells maize and gari (cassava) at Abrobeano, which she has been doing since 1999. She is married with five dependents; her husband is a fisherman. She has received no formal education.

Adwoa will use this loan to buy more goods for sale at the market. The profit she gets will be used to support her children’s education.

In front of Adwoa in the photo is a bowl of maize to represent what she sells.

loans.use: To buy more maize and gari for sale at the market.

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en:
Khursheda is married with three children. Hers is an average family from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. However, Khursheda is a unique entrepreneur. She has been selling shoes in the central city market for about 3 years, running her own small venture successfully. She also sells reels of thread, needles and other items for sewing. The secret of her success is simple: she tries to not only let her customers know the benefits of her products—she also gives them a sense of relationship which brings them back again and again. However, she doesn’t want to stop where she is now with her venture. Khursheda is seeking a loan of 3500 Somoni to restock the merchandise in her store for the winter season. We believe that Khursheda’s desire to excel in pleasing her customers will secure her further success and encourage new customers to buy from her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing winter boots for men

loans.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Madame A. Adjo est née à Hahotoé en 1967. Mariée et mère de six (06) enfants, elle vit actuellement à Aklakou. La vente de layette est sa principale source de revenu. De cette activité, sort un maigre bénéfice avec lequel, elle subvient difficilement aux besoins de la famille et à la scolarisation de ses enfants.
Malgré son dévouement, elle n’arrive pas toujours à joindre les deux bouts. Dotée d’une expérience de quinze ans dans cette activité, qui n’a jamais fait faillite, elle sollicite un financement pour augmenter son pouvoir d’achat afin d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Adjo A. was born in Hahotoé in 1967. She is married, has six children, and currently lives in Aklakou. Her main source of income is the sale of baby clothes. Her profit margin is thin and she has difficulties supporting her family and paying for her children's schooling. In spite of her dedication, she is not always able to make ends meet. She has 15 years of experience in this business and has never gone bankrupt. She is asking for a loan in order to increase her purchasing power so that she can improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell baby clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Panah

texts.en:
Panah Q. is a 40-year-old butcher who sells mutton and beef to the local people and restaurants. Panah started his business in 1999, when he borrowed some money from his relatives and opened a small butcher shop uptown. Now Panah rents a shop in the heart of the southern city of Azerbaijan.

Panah is married and has 2 adorable children whom he loves most of everything. He tries very hard to improve their living conditions. Pahan wants his children to get a good education. Now he would like to build his own store and for this purpose he has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD. Panah counts on your help!

loans.use: build his own butcher shop

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah S. is a trader. He operates a cassava milling machine. Gari producers bring their cassava to him for milling. He also sells gari - roasted cassava flour - at Abrobeano near Elmina, which he has been doing since 1998. He is married and has five dependents and his wife is also a trader. He has received no formal education.

Abdullah will use this loan to purchase more cassava to increase his gari production. He will then use the profit he gets to cater for his family and to educate his children.

In the picture you can see Abdullah standing by one of his milling machines.

loans.use: To buy more cassava for gari production.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
Née à Aklakou en 1959 où elle vit jusqu’à ce jour, Madame K. Akossiwa est une veuve avec cinq (05) enfants. Elle est seule à prendre en charge ses enfants. Par les maigres revenu tirés de son petit commerce de patte de maïs «Kom», elle a de la peine à répondre aux besoins de la famille.
Elle sollicite un financement pour se ravitailler en maïs et bois de chauffe afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et rehausser son pouvoir d’achat.
texts.en:
Born in 1959 in the city of Aklakou, where she resides to this day, Mrs. Akossiwa K., a widow, lives with her five (5) children. She is alone and responsible for the upbringing of her children. From the tiny revenues of her small business of making corn dough, she finds it difficult meeting the needs of her family.

She is requesting a loan to increase her stocks of corn and fire wood and expand her buying power to better serve her customers

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies of corn and fire wood

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en: Svitlana is married with two children. She lives in a small town of Storozhnytsya where she sells groceries and household necessities in a small retail store. Svitlana started this business 2 years ago. Because of her hard work, she has been able to offer more and more variety of goods and earn more income. She currently rents her store, but she dreams of owning her own little shop. She is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas (about $623) so continue to diversify the goods she sells and build more income towards realizing her dream.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Yalchin

texts.en:
Yalchin M. is a 31-year-old man who sells different kind of goods in a rented store in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He is married and has 2 adorable daughters. He started his business in 2000 and since that time he has a permanent and single income that his store brings in monthly.

Yalchin's dream is to provide his daughters with an excellent education. With this wish in his heart, he starts his working day early in the morning and finishes late at night. He would like to increase his income and one day build his own store. For this purpose he has applied for a loan in the amount of 1200 USD.

loans.use: purchase more inventory

loans.name: Laurent

texts.fr: Monsieur Laurent K. est né à Agbodrafo en 1972 et réside actuellement à Kpémé. Marié et père de deux (02) enfants, il a pour activité principale la vente de pétrole lampant et de lubrifiant pour motos. Monsieur Laurent dispose d’une bonne moralité et d’une capacité de gestion impeccable. Aujourd’hui, compte tenu de peu de moyens dont il dispose, il se voit incapable de satisfaire la demande qui est de plus en plus forte. Il sollicite alors un crédit pour relancer son activité. Ceci lui permettra de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et de la fidéliser. De ses revenus, il pourra mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Laurent K. was born in Agbodrafo in 1972 and currently lives in Kpémé. Married and the father of two children, his primary occupation is the sale of kerosene and lubricant for motorcycles. Mr. Laurent has strong sense of ethics and perfect management skills. Currently he does not have enough means to satisfy an increasing demand, so he is requesting a loan to boost his business. This will allow him to better meet the demands of his customers and earn their loyalty. With his income he will be able to better provide for his family.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of kerosene and lubricant

loans.name: Yaroslav

texts.en:
Yaroslav is married with two children. Their family lives in Uzhgorod, Western Ukraine. Yaroslav worked in construction and developed a passion for that work. Today he owns a manufacturing and processing workshop where he makes wooden windows and doors for local resorts. His processing machines make his business more efficient. He also uses his shop to repair cars, another source of income. His business provides jobs for ten employees, which is very important during these times of financial crisis and unemployment in the Ukraine.

Yaroslav has been running this business for 20 years. Yaroslav is seeking a 5000 Grivna (about $875) loan to purchase all necessary raw materials for a reconstruction project in the mountain resort town of Tyachiv. One of Yaroslav’s biggest dreams is to generate enough income to afford to take his whole family for a vacation. He is hoping this additional assistance will help him earn extra income and make his dream come true.

loans.use: To buy materials for a resort reconstruction project

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two children. She lives in Belaya Tserkov where she owns two vending locations in two different markets of her hometown. One is in the central marketplace and the other is at a local market called “Pischanyi”. Olga has been in business for 10 years, and she offers quality service that attracts many customers. 

Olga is requesting a 5,000 Grivna (about $875) loan that will be paid back in 12 months. She has just given birth to her second child. While she was pregnant, she couldn’t run her business she wasn't able to tend her business as diligently as she usually does. She will use her loan to get her business back to it's best working order by purchasing new inventory.  Olga's good character and strong business skills will enable her to expand and strengthen her business and increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a single Mom and is the sole support of her daughter. Her daughter’s father is an alcoholic and unable to help out. Victoria has to work hard to be able to provide for her daughter and pay all her bills. She runs a small vending business selling clothing items and linen sheets in the local markets in Levanevskyi district, Belaya Tserkov. She has just moved her vending location to a new market where she has purchased a container for her merchandise.

Victoria is requesting a loan of  5000 Grivnas (about $875) to increase her stock which will improve her sales. She has been running this trade for a year and a half. Victoria's first loan helped her double her inventory and complete renovation in her apartment, a costly project for a single mother. Lending assistance has also helped Victoria hire an employee and run her venture more smoothly and effectively while enabling another person to have a job.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Dégbémion

texts.fr:
Mariée, Madame T. Dégbémion est née le 02 février 1981 à Aného où elle exerce son petit commerce de vente d’assiettes et d'ustensiles de cuisines. C’est elle qui, par son dynamisme, fait face aux charges du foyer. Le manque de moyens financiers l’oblige à acheter en détail les assiettes et ustensiles qu’elle revend dans les quartiers et au grand marché de sa localité ; ce qui n’est pas de nature à lui garantir un revenu suffisant.
Aussi elle solliciter un financement afin d’aller s’approvisionner en gros, ce qui va réduire les couts    d'achat et de les revendre en détail dans sa localité. Ceci lui permettra de satisfaire la demande du marché et en de dégager de revenu plus consistant pour faire face aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dégbémion T. is married and was born February 2, 1981 in Aného where she runs a small business selling dishes and kitchen utensils. She is the one who supports her household through her activities. A lack of financial means has compelled her to buy dishes and utensils from retailers and sell them in neighborhoods and at the big market in her region. This activity that does not guarantee a sufficient income. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase products in bulk – which will reduce purchasing expenses – and to sell them as retail in her region. This will allow her to satisfy market demand and to earn a more consistent income to provide for her family.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of dishes and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed T. is a trader who also operates a corn milling machine at Abrubemu near Elmina. He has been doing this business since 2003. He is married and has eight dependents, and his wife is also a trader. He has received junior high school education.

Mohamed will use this loan to buy spare parts for his machine due to the fact that his machine has been developing problems. He will use the profit he gets to pay the school fees of his children and then use the rest to expand his business.

In the picture, Mohamed is in the process of milling corn which was brought by one of his customers.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to repair his milling machine.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy raw materials for making dresses, West African cloth, and sheets

loans.name: Anani Latévi

texts.fr:
Monsieur L. Anani Latévi est né en 1970 à Aného, il est marié et père de quatre (04) enfants. Son rêve est de devenir le plus grand des menuisiers de sa localité. Aujourd’hui le manque  de bois et de planches reste un handicap sérieux à la réussite de cet homme plein d’ambitions. 
Aussi voudrait-il commander de bois et de planches lui-même afin de répondre aux nombreuses sollicitations des clients. Les moyens financiers faisant défaut, il demande un financement pour passer cette commande dans les fermes et villages environnants afin de fidéliser ses clients actuels et rentabiliser son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Anani Latévi L. was born in 1970 in Aného. He is married and the father of four children. His dream is to become the primary carpenter in his neighborhood. Today, this ambitious man's success is hindered by a lack of wood and boards. He would like to order wood and boards himself in order to address the numerous requests of his clients. Since financial means are lacking, he is requesting a loan to place orders in surrounding farms and villages and earn the loyalty of his current customers, thus making his business more profitable.

Translated from French by Erin Johnson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wood and boards for carpentry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Agossi

texts.fr:
Née en 1963 à Aného, Madame H. Agossi est veuve et a à charge trois (03) enfants. N’ayant pas eu la chance de faire les études elle s’est vite lancée dans le commerce par la vente de la farine de manioc et  du tapioca; commerce à travers lequel elle se sacrifie chaque jour pour nourrir ses enfants qui vivent dans des conditions difficiles.

Son activité n’offre que de revenus instables et donc ne pouvant pas couvrir le besoin quotidien de cette famille. Décidée à donner une autre impulsion à son activité qui, du reste, est rentable, elle sollicite un financement pour acheter en grande quantité les produits et de les revendre afin de dégager plus de bénéfices qui serviront à relever le niveau de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Aného, Agossi H. is a widow with three children. Not having had the opportunity to attend school, at an early age she took up a trade, the sale of cassava flour and tapioca; She makes sacrifices every day for this business in order to feed her children who live in difficult conditions. Her business endeavors only provide an unstable income and therefore she cannot meet the day-to-day needs of her family. To provide her business with a stimulus to make it cost effective, Agossi is requesting a loan to buy products in bulk to sell to generate more profit, which will be used to raise her family’s standard of living.

Translated from French by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of cassava flour and tapioca

loans.name: Najma M. Akhtar Group

texts.en:
I am Najma and I reside in a city named Borewala, Pakistan.  I am a married woman and my husband's name is M. A. who is a watchman by profession.  

I have six kids: three daughters and three sons.  My elder daughter is in the 3rd standard and my elder son is in kindergarten.  The others are not at a school going age.  I am 29 years old.  

Since I was child I have loved education, but I couldn’t go to study because my parents wouldn’t allow me to go to school.  They suggested I stay at home and make embroidered dresses.  My mother taught me this art.  

When I got married and became a mother, I decided to give my children a good education because it has become essential in every walk of life.  

My husband’s earnings are not so good, but he wants to start a business of clothes selling.  I have successfully repaid my first loan, which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now I am applying for a loan to buy clothes to resell. 

I am a group leader of a few more members in my community.  Sajida Parveen Baji wants a loan to repair a vehicle named “Shahzore”.  I. A. Baji wants a loan to buy more mobile phones for her mobile phone selling business.  Mahnaz Baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell.  Salma Baji wants a loan to buy materials (sugar, milk and dry fruits) for her sweetmeat selling business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for a clothes selling business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 33 years old and is married with 4 children. She sells groceries. The demand for her groceries is high. She started this business in 2003. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Messan

texts.fr:
Mécanicien vulcanisateur de profession, Monsieur A. Messan est né en 1969 à Aného. Résidant à Kpémé où il exerce son métier de mécanicien, il est très connu de tous et très sollicité dans la localité. Il est marié et père de trois (03) enfants dont l’avenir lui tient beaucoup à cœur. Aussi tous ses efforts contribuent à subvenir à leurs besoins et à leur assurer un lendemain meilleur.
Mais ses moyens très limités constituent un sérieux handicap à tous ses projets et les crédits sollicités auprès des usuriers l’enfoncent de plus en plus dans la misère.
Pour réhabiliter son atelier et mieux servir ses clients, il sollicite un financement pour équiper son atelier et se ravitailler en pneus très recherchés sur place. Une telle diversification de son activité lui permettra d’augmenter ses revenus.
texts.en:
A tire mechanic by trade, Mr. Messan A. was born in 1969 in Aného. Residing in Kpémé where he practices his trade, he is well-recognized by all and in high demand in town. He is married and the father of three children, whose future he holds dearly to heart. Furthermore, all his efforts go towards providing for their needs and to ensure a better tomorrow for them. But his very limited means is a serious handicap to all of his plans. And the loans gotten from loan-sharks drag him lower and lower into poverty.

To rehabilitate his workshop and to serve his customers better, he is requesting financing to equip his shop and to get resupplied in highly sought-after tires, locally. Such diversification of his business will enable him to increase his income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up his workshop and to sell used tires

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero is 60 years old and she is a widow with 9 children. She sells plantains wholesale and retail to her customers. She started this business in 1992. She needs the loan of N50,000 to purchase more plantains to sell.  She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase plantains to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is 30 years old and is married with 4 children. She sells groceries and drinks. She started this business in 2001. Victoria is a LAPO client. She needs loan of N50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.  She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 60-year-old widow with 4 children. She sells plantains. The demands for her plantains are high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more plantains to sell. She says "thanks" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plantains to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 48 years old and is married with 4 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells goats. She says that this business is highly profitable. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs a loan of N100,000 to purchase more goats to sell. She says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase goats to sell

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate is 37years old and is married with 2 children. She sells newspapers to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. 

Kate is a LAPO client. She needs the loan of N100,000 to purchase more newspaper to sell. She says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase newspapers to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. She sells food. She started this business in 2005. She is a LAPO client. She needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more food to sell. She says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Chilimicenco

texts.en:
This client has grown and sold potatoes for 17 years. With her family, she cultivates of 1.62 hecaters of arable land. The loan will be used for digging a well to irrigate the potatoes. The practice of 17 years of client activity has proven that this business is profitable. There are competitors in the market, but sales are still going well. The monthly net income in the business season is about 5000-6000 Moldovan Leu. The profit from the business is directed towards strengthening the business.

This client has taken a loan from Microinvest in the past.

loans.use: Dig a well

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella E. is 37 years old and is married with 2 children. She is a fashion designer and she also sells tailoring supplies. She has been in this business for a long time. 

Stella needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more tailoring supplies to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring supplies to sell

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 25 years old and single. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has a store where she sells medicine. The demands for her medicines are high. 

Joy needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. Joy says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 30 years old and is married with 2 children. She sells newspapers. She loves this business, which she started in 2001. 

Mercy is a LAPO client. She needs loan of N40,000 to purchase more newspapers to sell. She says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase newspapers to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 41years old and is married with 6 children. She sells food and soup ingredients such as rice, beans, palm oil, melon seeds, and crayfish. She started this business in 2002. 

She needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more food and soup ingredients to sell. She says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and soup ingredients to sell

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina is 40 years old and is married with 5 children. She sells sarongs, bags and shoes at Oba market in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.. She travels to Onitsha to purchase the sarongs, bags and shoes that she sells in Benin City. 

She needs a loan of N70,000 to purchase more sarongs, bags and shoes to sell. She says "thank you" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase sarongs, bags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Darou Mboumbaye Group

texts.fr: L'écovillage de MbouM. est situé dans la région de Saint Louis à 300 km de Dakar. Les principales activités économiques dans la zone sont : le commerce, la pêche, le maraichage, l'élevage et l'extraction du sel. Les femmes du groupement de Darou MbouM.  ayant une trés grande expérience dans le domaine du maraîchage viennent auprès de Kiva pour solliciter un prêt. Avec le prêt, elles vont acheter des semences, de l'engrais, du fumier, des pulvérisateurs pour faire du maraîchage. Les produits récoltés, elles espèrent développer le marché local par la création d'un système d'approvisionnement et de commercialisation de fruits et légumes.
texts.en:
The ecovillage of MbouM. is located in the Saint Louis region about 300 kilometers away from Dakar. The main activities of the people inhabiting the region are: commerce, fishing, farming, raising animal and extracting salt. The women of Darou MbouM. have a lot of experience in farming and have come to Kiva in order to obtain a loan. With the money from the loan they will purchase seeds, fertilizer, manure and sprays to be able to grow fruits and vegetables. They are hoping that they will be able to create a local market and provide the local population with fruits and vegetables.

Translated from French by Jane Mazur, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertiliser

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia V. sells beef. She has been in this business since 2004. She is a LAPO client. Felicia hopes for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more beef to sell. She says "thanks" to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase beef to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is a trader. She sells cooked rice at Abrubemu and she has been doing this business since 1998. She is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a fisherman. She has received senior high school education.

Agnes will use the money from this loan to buy more rice to cook for sale. She will use the profits to build a new house.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to cook for sale.

loans.name: Francesca

texts.en: Francesca D. is a thirty-two-year-old married mother of six children. Fortunately, four of them are currently in school. She is very dedicated to her work and to her child. By her own effort and hard work through her business, Francesca has supported her daughter to finish junior high school. She owns and operates a clothing and cosmetics shop in the local market of Obuasi where she lives. She believes she can grow her business through a Kiva loan; she plans to use the loan to buy more clothing materials and assorted cosmetics to increase her stock of goods. She believes this will help her to send her daughter to senior high school next year. She belongs to the community group called All Nations Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral for the loan loan. She does not sell on group meeting days, and her picture was taken during the meeting.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials and assorted cosmetics

loans.name: Lardi

texts.en: Lardi A. is a thirty-year-old mother of two children, both of whom are in school. She is hard-working and resourceful in caring for her family. She trades in charcoal and bags of maize, and she also sells food in her neighborhood. Lardi prepares kenkey: kenkey is prepared from milled maize and it is packaged in maize leaves and left to boil for two hours; it’s then served with hot pepper or any gravy together with fried fish. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. Lardi obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Obuasi, where she lives, and resells it to her customers. She wants to use this loan to stock up on supplies of charcoal, maize, fish and vegetables to increase her inventory especially during this Christmas season when demand for her goods is high. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase her savings to pay her children’s educational fees and also to save some money to buy Christmas dresses and shoes for her children. She belongs to the community group called Osenkafo, meaning Evangelist Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral for repaying the loan.

loans.use: To buy charcoal, maize, fish, and other supplies in bulk

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. is a trader. She sells soft drinks and rice at Abrubemu, which she has been doing since 2004. She is married with two children and her husband is a fisherman. She has received no formal education.

Sarah intends to use this loan to buy more soft drinks and rice to sell; she will use part of the profit she gets to expand her business and will save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks and rice to sell.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget knits cardigans and sells them wholesale and retail. She started her business in 2006. She is 28 years old and single. She needs a loan amount of N70,000 ($600) to purchase additional materials to knit more cardigans to sell. She is a LAPO client. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase materials for knitting cardigans to sell

loans.name: Las Pioneras De Chijini De Rsr Group

texts.es: El grupo LAS PIONERAS D. CHIJINI RSR representadas por la señora Elsa Amalia esta conformada por doce personas todas del mismo barrio,  los socios (as) tienen negocio estables como ser venta D. llantas, D. víveres, chompas tejidas a mano, comida, edredones, juguetes y otros, algunas D. las socias tienen otros ingresos a parte del comercio al cual se dedican. Los socios (as) D. este grupo trabajaron con anterioridad con la Fundación Agrocapital por lo que tienen experiencia en grupos solidarios, a pesar que estuvieron ausentes por unos cuantos meses volvieron a retomar el grupo para un nuevo financiamiento destinarlo a la compra D. materia prima,  mercadería y estocar mejor sus productos para venderlos en el mercado central, en anteriores financiamiento este grupo demostró honestidad, responsabilidad y la capacidad D. administrar bien sus bienes para poder cumplir con todos sus objetivos que principalmente son buscar una mejor estabilidad económica para sus familias.
texts.en:
The LAS PIONERAS D. CHIJINI RSR group represented by Señora Elsa Amalia is composed of twelve persons all from the same neighborhood. The members have stable businesses such as selling tires, provisions, hand-woven sweaters, take-out food, comforters, toys, and other things. Some of the members have other income in addition to their business. The members of this group worked previously with Fundación Agrocapital, so they have experience with support groups. Although they were inactive for several months, they started the group up again for new financing for the purpose of buying raw materials and merchandise to improve their stock of products to sell in the central market. In their former financing this group demonstrated honesty, responsibility, and the ability to manage their goods such that they could accomplish all their objectives, primarily seeking better financial stability for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa O. is 39 years old. She is a wife and mother with two children. She is resourceful and very enterprising. She has supported one child through high school and is now waiting to enter university. The other one is currently in school. She operates a local restaurant and sells local food like banku-and-okro soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is eaten with hot pepper or soup. She says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she is no longer able to afford her normally high quality.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi O. sells provisions and drinks. The demands for her provisions and drinks are high. She started this business in 2000. Ngozi needs a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. Ngozi says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary D. is 39 years old, widowed and the mother of five children. Her children are all currently in school.  Mary has been selling frozen food in the local market of Obuasi for two years, but she says profit is very low because she pays high rent on the store she operates, and the electricity cost is also high because she shares the power with a nearby shop. She wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen food to enable her to raise enough money to buy a permanent store for herself and stock her inventory before Christmas, which is a busy season for frozen foods sales. She is a member of the group called All Nations. Members in this group guarantee and support one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy cartons of frozen food

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en:
Ana is a member of the Sumaq Huayta Village Bank; “Sumaq Huayta” means “Beautiful Flower” in Quechua. Ana is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their six children. Ana sells vegetables in different villages around the Ayacucho region, where she travels three times a week, and buys grains in the towns she visits. Ana Maria needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy grains and vegetables. Ana’s dreams are to improve her business, to have more investment capital, and for all of her children to graduate with professional degrees.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow Ana es socia del Banco Comunal Sumaq Huayta que significa Linda Flor.

Ana es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 6 hijos, Ana vende verduras que vende en los diferentes pueblos de la región a donde viaja 3 veces por semana y de los pueblos compra cereales variados.

Ana Maria necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cereales y verduras. Los sueños de Ana son mejorar su negocio, tener mas capital y que todos sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy grains and vegetables

loans.name: Picaflor Group

texts.es: El grupo "Picaflor" esta conformado por 12 socios (as) las cuales tienen diferentes actividades, como  la venta D. Discos compactos, ropa D. bebe, joyas, muebles, prendas D. vestir pero la mas sobre saliente es el tejido D. mantas y chompas las cuales se las comercializan en diferentes feria que existe en la ciudad en las cuales se realiza la venta al por mayor. Los socios (as) van cursando su cuarto ciclo trabajando con la fundación Agrocapital en los cuales demostraron honestidad y responsabilidad en sus pagos, los financiamientos anteriores ha llevado a las socias a poder mejorar sus productos y a mejora la calidad D. vida D. sus familias. el actual financiamiento esta destinada la compra D. materia prima o incremento D. mercadería para la venta así como para la compra D. herramientas D. trabajo para mejorar la calidad D. sus productos y maximizas su producción en especial la textil.
texts.en:
The "Picaflor" group consists of 12 members having different activities such as selling compact discs, baby clothing, jewelry, furniture, and articles of clothing, but the most outstanding are the woven blankets and sweaters which are sold in the different street markets in the city, where they sell them wholesale. The members are entering their fourth loan cycle working with the Agrocapital foundation, with whom they have demostrated honesty and responsibility in their repayment. The previous loans have enabled the members to improve their products as well as the quality of life of their families.
