loans.use: To purchase additional supplies to sell in her store

loans.name: Thaing's Group

texts.en:
The three members of this group loan live in Spean Thnoat Commune, Siem Reap Province. Mrs. Thaing A., 32 year old mother of three children, is the group leader. She grows rice and vegetable crops as a local farmer. Her husband, Kvan Hann, is a 34 year old fisherman from Tunle Sap Lake. He sells his fish in the market and earns approximately $5 each day. To earn additional income, A. would like to start a new family business in pig breeding. She has a pigpen behind her house and would like to purchase piglets to raise. 

The other borrowers in this group include Pin H., a 24 year old rice farmer. She seeks a loan to buy rice and resell for profit. Also, Luy P. is a 26 year old local farmer who requests a loan to buy piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M., a 49-year-old mother, is a food vendor. She has spent her whole life working to help her family and support her children. Her husband is a farmer who helps her run her business and she is doing her best to send all her children to school and provide them with a good future.

Josephine needs a loan to purchase additional ingredients and food items to sell. She cooks food as well as selling vegetables to earn a living. She also is looking at some other possible income areas to address her family's needs.

In an interview she said, “CEVI has given me a chance to change our lives. They provide us with credit assistance so our business can grow, with training for social growth and insurance coverage for our security and protection.”

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and food items to sell

loans.name: Madelyn

texts.en:
Madelyn has been living at Brgy. Malamag East Tumauni, Isabela since 2000. She is married to Edgardo who is an expert house carpenter. They are blessed with three children aged thirteen, twelve and three.

She set up a small village store in 2004 and her husband started their furniture shop in 2006 in order to augment their income. The skills of her husband as a carpenter has been a great advantage to their shop because the furniture they make like wooden cabinets, dining set, chairs and tables are being sold easily. Currently, they are thinking of getting a loan of PHP5,000 as their additional capital. It will be used in buying various products to be sold in her store and the needed materials in their furniture making business like soft wood.  

When they have enough savings, they plan to have their house repaired and of course to further improve their business. But foremost in their dream is to see their children finish college.

loans.use: buy additional items to sell in her store and materials needed in the furniture shop

loans.name: Majuline

texts.en:
Majuline T. is married to a farmer and they have three children. She opened up a small store located closer to her village, so her fellow villagers don't need to travel too far into town to buy basic commodities.

The income from their store has helped Majuline's family in their daily needs. They are thinking of buying additional products in order to earn more profit and to be able to save for their children's education and for their future.They thought of asking a loan of PHP7,000 from a local financial institution that helps people like them who dream to have a better life.

If she would be given the amount that she borrows, she promised to pay them off timely.
  
With her passion in managing her business, she believes that her family's living status will improve.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Marivi Joie

texts.en:
Marivi Joie A., a 30-year-old mother of two children, from Calumpang, General Santos City, is an entrepreneur. She wishes to have a good life for her family, to be able to send all of her children to school, and provide all the things they need.

Her life is fully focused on how she could meet all the needs of her children. She wanted to change their lives so she joined CEVI's credit program and established her own business.

She retails a variety of goods to all her neighbors to earn family income. The money she earns from selling goods is what she uses to buy food for the family and pay for her children's schooling.

She needs a loan to purchase additional stock to sell in her store. In this way she will be able to compete well among her competitors and earn a bigger income from her business.

Now that she is part of CEVI's credit program, she has access to the credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage CEVI offers to all its clients.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell in her store

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K. is 26 years old, married, with three young children. Her family lives in Siem Reap Province. She is a local farmer who grows rice or vegetable crops. Her husband, Ream Vann, is a 28 year old fisherman who earns approximately $2.50 per day. Recently, his fishing equipment was broken thus he has not been able to catch as much fish as before. Therefore, Sok K. is requesting a loan to buy more fishing tools to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To buy more fishing tools

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Maritess lives in Brgy. Cabisera 18 Ilagan, Isabela, is married to a rice and corn farmer named Patricio. They are blessed with four children aged 23, 21, 14 and 2. They have not sent any of their children to college because they do not have the money to support their education, but they dream to send their third child in college soon through the help of their business.

Maritess' small store has been a great help not only to her family, but to her fellow villagers since they can get their daily needs without going into town. She also offers reasonable prices and even provides credit to those with good paying capacity.  

She wants to add more products in her store to maximize her income but she does not have the needed money so she is asking for a loan of PHP7,000 to fulfill her plan. A portion of the loan proceeds will be also used to finance their farm.

She also dreams to eventually have a grocery store since she believes that her 18 years of experience in managing a store is enough to run a bigger store. They firmly believe they will be able to send their two youngest children to college and provide a better life for their family by helping each other.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Merita

texts.en:
Merita is married to Domingo, a farmer, and they have two children- Joshua- 13 years old and Dennis- 14 years old, and both are in their first year of high school.

Merita manages her own village store and needs additional working capital to be able to start another business of cooking a variety of snacks (made of noodles).  She thinks it will give her additional income but she does not have enough money to make it happen. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP4,000 to start her food business.  Part of the loan proceeds will be used to purchase additional products like coffee, soft drinks, cooking oil, fish sauce and canned goods to be sold in her store.

Despite their simple way of living, she is happy because they are healthy and her store is doing well.  She aims to continuously manage her business well to earn more income and save for the education of her two sons.

loans.use: buy additional products for her store and start a food business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Selling fruit, fish, flowers, building materials. Raising pigs and chickens.

loans.name: Trang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Trang K., 44 years old, is the leader of a group loan from Ratanak Commune in Battambang Province. She is a baker who makes banana cakes and sells them from her home. For over three years, she has earned approximately $3 a day from this business. Out of her four children, her first son is a security guard for a company and her second son is a construction worker. K. is applying for a loan to buy more cake ingredients for her business. 

There are two other members of this group loan. Mrs. Touch N., age 44, is a fritter seller who needs a loan to purchase construction materials for her husband's business. Mrs. Lun P. is 35 years old, earns an income by selling dessert. She is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more cake ingredients

loans.name: Hoa Thi's Group

texts.vi:
Hoàng Thị Hoà sinh năm 1969 ( Mã Số 010117050049 )  tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ bán hoa quả. vợ chồng chị có ba con đang độ tuổi đi học. Hàng ngày, chị đi chợ bán hoa quả đem lại thu nhập khoảng 90.000 vnđ/ ngày. Chồng chị cũng đi làm thuê nên thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ/ tháng. Với thu nhập theo ngày, vốn vay trả góp theo tuần, gia đình chị rất thích và mong muốn tham gia vay vốn lâu dài tại tổ chức tài chính vi mô Bình minh. Trong nhóm chị còn có:
 Phạm Ngọc Thuyên sinh năm 1970 ( Mã Số 010117050043 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ cá.
 Trần Thị Lan sinh năm 1948 ( Mã  số 010117050044 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.
 Nguyễn Thị Ninh sinh năm 1963 ( Mã  số 010117050045 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ cá.
 Đặng Thị Trang sinh năm 1964 ( Mã  số 010117050046) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ.
 Đỗ Thị Nguyên sinh năm 1962 ( Mã  số 010117050047 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư kinh doanh v ật liệu xây dựng.
 Nguyễn Thị Hoa sinh năm 1970 ( Mã  số 010117050048 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đi chợ bán hoa.
 Trần Thị Thuỷ sinh năm 1985 ( Mã  số 010117050050 ) tham gia vay vốn mức vay: 4.142.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoa Thi H., the SEDA fund ID 010117050049, is a 39 years old woman. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell fruit. She and her husband have three small children in school age. Every day she sells fruit in the local market; income from this selling is usually 90,000 Vietnamese Dong per day. Her husband is a worker, whose income is 3,500,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. With support from the SEDA fund, the couple now has chance to improve their live; they plan to build a long-term partnership with the fund. In the group there are following individuals: Ms. Thuyen Ngoc P., 38 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050043, wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell fish. Ms. Lan Thi T., 60 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050044, wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise pigs. Ms. Ning Thi N., 45 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050045, wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell fish. Ms. Trang Thi D., 44 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050046, wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to start selling small items. Ms. N. Thi D., 46 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050047, to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell construction material. Ms. Hoa Thi N., 38 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050048, wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to sell flowers. Ms. Thuy Thi T., 23 years old, the SEDA fund ID 010117050050 wants to borrow 4,142,000 Vietnamese Dong to raise chicken.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc T., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Small businesses

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Mrs. Gina C. is 43 years old, married, with 3 children. The eldest child already finished his studies but as of now he is still working as contractual employee. The 2nd child is elementary pupil; while the youngest is in daycare. Her husband is a maintenance worker at Oil Depot Company in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental.

Since she has an existing "sari-sari" (variety) store she decided to build a space for her videoke sound system for her customers. On this purpose she can invite more customers to sing on her Videoke sound system.

She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative 3 years ago, she is very helpful and cooperative to her co-group members in Isla Camongay Center, Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 and this loan is intended for purchasing additional construction materials for her Videoke sound system location.

 Her future plan to her family is to live a comfortable life and to be able to renovate her house.

loans.use: Purchase additional contruction materials for her Videoke space

loans.name: May Annelieze

texts.en:
Mrs. May Annelieze D., is  42 years old, married, and blessed with 4 children. Her husband is an auditor in MHARS General hospital, Ozamiz City. As of now 2 of her children are studying in college as Nursing Student and the other 2 are elementary pupils. 
 
Even though her husband has a permanent job, she needs extra income because of economic crisis and 2 of her children are college students. That’s why she decided to engage in Ready-to-Wear (RTW) Clothes retailing. Since her capital to her business is not sufficient she decided to join Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative because she heard from her neighbor that the cooperative is offering livelihood programs and microfinancing services.

The PMPC became a great help to her business because she was able to put up additional capital to her RTW Business. She is a member in good standing in  Sampaguita Center, Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 14,900 to purchase additional RTW clothes for sale.

Mrs. D. plans to have an additional quality stocks of RTW clothes for her business and enable her college students finish their studies.

loans.use: Purchase additional ready to wear clothes

loans.name: Ibodat

texts.ru: Негматуллаева Ибодат женщина в возросте 51 год мать четверых детей, которая уже 6 год кредитуется в Микроинвесте.Сейчас у нее товарооборот составляет 12000 сомони.Она начанала с малого бизнеса.Теперь ей для приобретения зимнего ассортимента она хочет получить 3500 сомони. Ибодат торгует на рынке Худжанда материалами для пошива верхней одежды.Эта женщина одна из пунктуальных клиентов Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Ibodat N. is 51 years old and a mother of four children. It's her sixth year since she started taking loans at MicroInvest. At this time, her inventory turnaround consists of 12000 somoni (USD$3,600). She started with a small business. Right now she wants to get a loan for 3500 somoni to buy winter materials. Ibodat sells fabrics and supplies for outerwear on the Khudjanda market. This woman is one of the most punctual clients of MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma owns a junk shop in their community and is married to Rolly who is a tricycle driver. They were blessed with four children namely: Aubrey- 2 years old, Myka- 4 years old, Ronez- 6 years old and Adrian- 7 years old, and they are all in elementary school. 

With only a small capital, Norma was able to start her own junk shop.  She buys materials that can be recycled like empty bottles, scrap metals, galvanized iron, plastic bottles and wares in their community and other nearby villages. 

Aside from the junk shop, she also manages her bakery store in the village. This serves as their other source of income. She is currently in need of a machine to be used in her bakeshop but does not have excess money to buy one. She is applying for a loan amounting to PHP5, 000 to acquire machine and employ a helper in her junk shop. 
	
She strongly believes that God gave mercy to those who really walk righteously and work diligently. So, Norma and her husband are working hand in hand in order to survive and prepare for the future of their children by giving them a good education.

loans.use: buy machine and employ a helper

loans.name: Pienita

texts.en:
Pienita and her husband are photographers and videographers that manage a photo/video studio. The income from the studio enables them to support their two daughters aged eight and seven who are both in elementary school. They have a small happy family.

Their business which started its operation in 2003 is doing well. They are always being called upon during special occasions like graduations, nuptials, baptismals, birthdays and other important events. They also offer photo lamination and framing. 

Currently, they are planning to get a loan of PHP15,000 as additional capital for their business. The loan proceeds will be used to buy additional items like photo films, batteries, blank tapes for video recording, and more, which are often being asked by customers from their studio.

Their ultimate goals is for their children to have a better life and to grow with God's guidance.

loans.use: buy items for sale and needed in their photo studio

loans.name: Marlon

texts.en:
Marlon S. is a 36 year old tricycle driver and is married to Emma. While Marlon is busy bringing people to their destinations through his tricycle, Emma stays at home to take care of their two children and do the household chores. 

His income as a tricycle operator is only PHP1, 700 a week. They have to budget this for their daily expenses and for their children's school allowance. Because of the limited income, Marlon is thinking of putting up a hog raising business which requires a start-up capital of PHP 4,000. This will be used to buy two piglets and enough animal feed.  

With hard work and perseverance, Marlon knows, they will be able to surpass life's challenges. Despite the hardships and pressures in life, Marlon makes sure to always have good health for he believes that “health is wealth”. 

“I want to give my children a better future. I want them to finish their studies that is why I am really working hard because I am the only one who provides for our family," Marlon said.

loans.use: buy 2 piglets and feeds to start a hog raising business

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Mr. Seng L. lives in the village of Pdau Chum Koeut  in the Kampong Cham Province of Cambodia. He is in the business of charging batteries. His wife, Mrs. Kai Eang, is a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Mr. Seng L. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food to expand his wife's business. He hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan. Mr. Seng L. is 53-years-old and the father of two children who stay at home to do housework.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food for his wife's pig breeding business.

loans.name: Masuma

texts.ru: Масума женщина которой 42 года замужняя, имеющая одного ребенка. Масума торгует на рынке мужской одеждой.За товаром она ездиет в Истаравшан. У неё небольшой лорёк, она хочет получив займ закупить зимний ассортимент.Она уже хочет получить очередной второй займ. Первый кредит она закончила отлично.
texts.en:
Masuma is a 42 year old woman, married with one child. She sells men's clothing at a market. She travels to Istaravshan to buy the goods. She has a small vending space, and used a loan to buy winter inventory. She already wants to obtain a second loan. The first loan she completed successfully.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Menswear

loans.name: Mak

texts.en:
Mrs. Mak Y. is 49-years-old and lives in Kradas Khor village in the Kampong Cham Province of Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her field has infertile soil which affects her crop in a negative way. In order to have more success with her business, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve her crop yields.

Her husband, Mr. Chen Chim, owns a plow which he rents for income, to the villagers to plow their fields. Mrs. Mak Y. has a child who is a farmer. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and make her rice crop more productive.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora's family lives in Brgy. Fermeldy Tumauini, Isabela. Teodora and her husband Felipe have five children- three that are in high school, and two who are  high school graduates.

Teodora goes around the village to sell vegetables and other food items, and Felipe tills their farm land. Their combined income is not enough to support their family. Teodora would like to buy additional variety of products to sell in the community. She will need PHP 3,000 to do this but does not have excess money so she is applying a loan to a local financial institution which has a branch in their town. The money will be used to purchase different kinds of vegetables, chicken, fish, pig, and beef which will be sold in the community.

With the increase in their income, she expects to have her own stall and provide a good education to their children.

loans.use: buy various vegetables, meats for sale in the village

loans.name: Rann

texts.en:
Mrs. Rann T. lives in Tumnop Ang village in the Kampong Speu province in Cambodia. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Thoeun, sells firewood. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their household. In order to improve their conditions, Mrs. Rann T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding in hopes of increasing her income after she sells her cow.

She is 29-years-old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the youngest one is too young and stays at home. Her husband is on the right on the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Ray

texts.en:
Mrs. Ray R. is 18-years-old and lives in Svay Prey village in the Kampong Cham Province in Cambodia. She is a duck breeder. Since her ducks are growing larger, she does not have enough money to support them. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to request a loan to buy duck food. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions after she sells her ducks.

Her husband, Mr. Khorn Sokkhea, is a farmer who owns a piece of land and cultivates rice. Her husband is with her in the picture.

loans.use: To request for a loan to buy duck food for business.

loans.name: Keumson

texts.en:
Mrs. Keumson O. is a villager who lives in Sro Mor Village in the Kampong Cham Province in Cambodia. She has a small plot of land and cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Veng Huy, is a duck breeder. Since his ducks are growing larger, he does not have enough money to feed them so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more duck food for her husband's business.

Mrs. Keumson O. is 40-years-old and the mother of five children. Two of the children are laborers, two others are attending the local school and the youngest one, age five, is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more duck food for her husband's duck breeding business.

loans.name: Chhoar

texts.en:
Mr. Chhoar C. was born in 1966 and now lives in Sro Mor Village in the Kampong Cham Province in Cambodia. He and his wife are laborers who make a little income but are unable to provide better conditions for their household.

Additionally, Mr. Chhoar C. has difficulty providing fresh water for his household because he does not have enough money to dig a well. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Chhoar C. decided to ask for a loan to have the funds to dig the well. They have six children, one of whom is an immigrant working in Thailand, another child is employed in a garment factory, and the remaining three are laborers. His wife is with him in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to dig a well to supply fresh, clean water.

loans.name: Rosevida

texts.en:
Rosevida B. is a patient mother to her ten children.
	
In their barangay (Malamag East Tumauini, Isabela), Rosevida is an active leader at the moment. Their village is best described as a flat rural area with corn and tobacco as their main products in the village. Her family lives there happily, God-fearing and has a harmonious relationship with each other. 

In the village, Rosevida manages her small store where she sells basic commodities for the families who want to minimize their expenses in going to the market. Because of this reason, Rosevida wants to add varieties of products to sell in her store so she will be able to meet all the needs of her regular customers. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP8, 000 to be able to do this. 

"It is better to give than to receive” is her principle in life. Rosevida believes that giving without expecting in return is much acknowledged by God. At the moment, Rosevida gives her best towards the success of her business to support her family without being dependent to her children who now have their own jobs.

loans.use: buy additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Keomtouch

texts.en:
Mrs. Keomtouch E. is a villager in Sro Mor Village in the Kampong Cham Province in Cambodia. She is poultry breeder and raises ducks. Since her ducks are growing larger, she does not have enough money to feed them and is requesting a loan to buy more duck food.

Her husband, Mr. Yoem Bunthoeurn, is a policeman who makes a small salary to support the family. Mrs. Keomtouch E. is 31-years-old and the mother of three children. One is a laborer, while the remaining two are attending the local school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more duck food for her duck breeding business.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia lives in Barangay San Mateo Tumauini, Isabela which is known for its clean and green movement that encourages all its residents to have their own backyard garden planted with different kinds of vegetables. The progress of their village can be seen in its road conditions, street lights, health center, and Barangay Hall. Most villagers are engaged in farming, mainly corn and rice production. 

With the help of her husband Arnel, Virginia operates a beauty salon in their village. Their income from the salon supports their three children namely: Arvie- 12, Arjene- 11, and Jhenel- 9 who are all in the primary level of education. 

After almost eight years of managing a beauty parlor and five years in a small restaurant, Virginia is able to support their daily living and purchased their stall in the public market. She opens her stall at 6:00 in the morning and closes it at 7:00 in the evening unless there are still customers who need tending. At present, she wants a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 for the renovation of the beauty salon so that it will become more comfortable for her customers. Also, part of the loan proceeds will be used in her restaurant to buy raw foods like vegetables, meat, fish, chicken, other ingredients, etc.

Since all her children are still studying in elementary school, Virginia must exert more effort to work hard in order to improve her business and therefore save for the future education of her children.

loans.use: Renovation of beauty salon and purchase of raw foods and ingredients for the restaurant

loans.name: Namasuba H- Ndagire Salome Group

texts.en:
Salome N. is 27 years old. She is a hardworking single mother of three children, who are between the ages of four and seven. She is also a loving guardian to her two brothers who came into her care after the death of their parents.

Using money saved from selling charcoal, Salome opened up a cosmetics shop two years ago. She created the shop by partitioning part of her residence in Namasuba. She sells perfumes, hair additions, hair relaxers, and lotions, among other things. These sales earn her a minimum profit of UGX 60,000 per week. Besides, she also sells safe piped-water to households in her locality at the rate of UGX 50 per jerrican.

She would therefore use the loan to purchase cosmetics, like Movit relaxer and treatment, TCB Naturals, botanical marrow, mayonnaise treatment, Venus, and Dark & Lovely, among others. This added inventory will allow her to meet the rising demands of customers and also compete favourably in the market. She has an ambition to open up a ladies' boutique and also ensure those entrusted into her care go through their education successfully at all levels.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and hair products in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Bienvenida

texts.en:
Mrs. Bienvenida G., 44 years old, is married with 2 children. Her husband is a mere tenant-farmer who raises coconut, banana and root crops for a living.

Mrs. G. is finding ways to have additional income in order to send her 2 children to high school. Since her husband's income was not enough to support the education, she decided to become a Personal Collection (a cosmetic company) dealer and sell other products just to gain other extra income for her family.

She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative 3 years ago because of the programs and services being offered. She is a member in good standing and very participative to her group and members of the Coop.

She is now requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 for purchasing additional stocks of her Personal Collection products. 

Her future plans for her family is to have a good life and hopes to renovate her house someday.

loans.use: To purchase additional cosmetic products for sale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 52 years old and she is married with 4 children. She sells cosmetics. She started this business in 2001. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says, "thanks" to all of the people that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Elsia

texts.en: Elsia is 44 years old and is married, with 5 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She has a shop where she sells CDs. Elsia started this business in 2006. She is requesting a loan to purchase more CDs to sell.  She says, "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more CDs to sell

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
In the peaceful village of Maribojoc, Tudela, Misamis Occidental with 200 households, lives Mrs. Esterlita D.. She is 56 years old, married, with 7 children. Four of her children got married and 3 are still single. Her husband is a farmer. Rice production is their main source of income and occasionally he does carpentry jobs for their neighbors as requested. 

Her little sari-sari (variety) store was started 10 years ago. She personally handles her little business in order for them to generate income. Aside from her store she is also raising swine and native chicken.

It’s been 3 years since she became a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and she admired so much the programs and services. She is a member in good standing and very cooperative and helpful to her members. She is now requesting a loan of  PHP 14,900.00 for purchasing additional grocery stocks to her store.

What she plans right now is to renovate her house and be able to have additional stocks to her business.

loans.use: Purchase additional grocery stocks for her store

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She sells second-hand clothes to people who cannot currently afford new clothes. She started this business in 2007. She is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says "thank you" to all of the people who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Namasuba H-Nansuna Aisha Group

texts.en:
It has been one year since Aisha N. ventured into the business of selling second-hand clothes in different markets around the city. She wakes up very early each Monday and Wednesday morning and heads to Owino Market in Kampala where she buys clothes from other traders. She gets a minimum profit of UGX 60,000 from weekly sales, which on many occasions she reinvests into the business to generate more income. She will use this loan to purchase dresses, skirts, blouses, trousers, and suits.

Hardworking Aisha aspires to open up a cosmetics shop. She was formerly a sales personnel in a kids wear shop in Kampala, and it is from her earnings that she put aside some savings as capital for the clothes business. Aisha is a married mother of four and also guardian to three of her late brother’s children. Her wish is to have an educated, healthy, and sustainable family.

loans.use: To purchase dresses, skirts, blouses, trousers, and suits to sell.

loans.name: Tutinisso

texts.en:
B. Tutinisso first applied to MicroInvest in 2003 and she is glad of its co-operation. Thanks to the previous loans, she improved the existing business and to open the new one. She traded before in eggs but now she has opened a new business selling different New Year toys, ornaments and such. She works with the suppliers so she trades at low prices and has repeat customers. She has a big assortment.

Mrs. B. is an active client of MicroInvest; she has not any delays in previous loans repayment. She increased the loan sum, which shows her business income increase. Now Mrs. B. Tutinisso applies the KIVA with the request for a loan of 2300 STJ for 6 months to increase her assortment.

loans.use: Increase her assortment of ornaments

loans.name: Ehiorobo

texts.en: Ehiorobo is 50 years old and is married, with 3 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She started this business in 2004. She is requesting a loan to puchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says, "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Namasuba H-Mpagi Ruth Group

texts.en:
Ruth M. is 27 years old and was once a cashier with the Ugandan development bank. She is a married mother of one and also a caring guardian to her late brother’s son. Two years back her dear husband, an architect by profession, set up a hardware shop for her in Najjanakumbi. With her hard work, she has been able to keep the business running effectively and efficiently. She earns a profit of approximately UGX 120,000 per week, which enables her to pay her rent of UGX 200,000 every month. The income from the business helps her put food on the table for her family in a shared role with the husband.

Ruth would use this loan to purchase water and oil-based Sadolin paints, locks, sandpapers, wood vanishes, and 6 mm glasses. The main challenge in her business is delayed payments by debtors but she has managed to control that by taking on a cash-on-delivery principle. She dreams of starting up a restaurant and raising a successful family.

loans.use: To purchase products to expand her hardware store.

loans.name: Marilizabeth

texts.en:
Marilizabeth, or “Beth” as she is fondly called in their village, is 29 years old and still single. She lives with her parents and helps them earn their daily living. They live in Barangay San Mariano, Isabela which is located at the back of their town's public market. 

Beth manages a sari-sari store (a community-based store) in their village wherein she is able to generate a weekly income of PHP 2,000 which is used as a revolving capital in her business and to support the needs of their family while her parents are managing their small farm despite their old age.  

She wants a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy additional products in her store. Beth also intends to use some of her loan to assist her parents financially in their farming needs. She also dreams of developing her store into a mini grocery so she could meet the needs of their fellow villagers.  

“Whenever I feel exhausted due to financial problems, I always think of the word perseverance so that I will be inspired again to face the hardships in life,” Beth said.

loans.use: Buy more products to sell in her store and support her family's farming needs

location.town: Old San Mariano, San Mariano Isabela

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha S. N. is a registered nurse who lives with her husband and their 3 children, a 14-year-old boy and two girls who are 12 and 2 years old, in Nakuru, Kenya. Tabitha owns and runs the Matutu Medical Clinic located in her community.

The clinic is 3 years old and provides services of general medical treatment, provider-initiated testing and counseling on HIV/AIDS, pre-natal and post-natal care, and family planning. In the near future, Tabitha will also offer child welfare programs and post-abortion care for women who have suffered from illicit abortions.

Before starting the clinic, Tabitha was working in a large hospital. She ended her employment there when she saw the need in her own local community for a medical provider, and she opened up a small clinic where she employs one other person. Tabitha has a good flow of patients, but as they are all of low income, she does not have a strong profit margin.

Tabitha is applying for a loan of 90,000 Kenya Schillings in order to improve her clinic and the services it provides to the community. With the loan money she will purchase equipment such as a pressure cooker to sterilize instruments, a speculum, and a patient examination couch. Tabitha wants to expand the clinic and will use some of the loan money to pay the rent for another room in her building. She also wants to repaint and partition off space for a waiting room for her clients.

loans.use: To purchase medical equipment and make clinic renovations.

loans.name: Lufuka C-Nansuna Sarah Group

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 32 years old. She was formerly a waitress in the Speke Hotel Kampala. She now operates a restaurant and a charcoal selling stall in Lufuka. She earns a weekly profit of at least UGX 80,000 from both businesses, which have been in operation since 2004. From her profits she settles her rent bills at the rate of UGX 60,000. Sarah is using the loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal to boost her charcoal selling business. Her strength in business is the ability to attract new customers while retaining old customers by offering them quality services.

However, she is not contented with these businesses because her dream is to run a wholesale shop of fast moving consumer goods. She hopes that by achieving her dream, she will be in position to set up a modern residence for her family and also see her children through best schools. She is a loving mother of four and also a caring guardian to her late brother's two children. Her loving husband is a businessman in the clothing sector and has always supported her in the businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Serapio

texts.en:
“My goals at the moment are to maintain our stable life, support the education of my adopted son, and to maintain our good health. I learned not to depend on my children’s income and to work harder for myself and for my adopted son who serves as my motivation to dream and continue with my life,” said Serapio, a widower from Barangay Binarzang Quirino, Isabela. 

Serapio is 53 years old and a resident of a peaceful and progressive community. He was left with three responsible children: Jimmylyn– 27 years old, is a college undergraduate and now working as a domestic helper in Hong Kong; Marilou– 24 years old, is a college graduate and also a domestic helper, and Servillano– 22 years old, is a high school graduate and now working as a security guard in Manila. He also has an adopted son, a 7-year-old named Julius who is already an elementary student.  

He is engaged in a hog raising business and is requesting a loan of PHP 4,000.00 to buy additional hogs in order to double his income within three to four months since he currently has only one hog in his pigpen.  

Serapio still believes in the saying: “try and try until you succeed” and, despite his age, still brings out his best in work to succeed in his endeavors.

loans.use: Buy additional hogs

loans.name: Rolan

texts.en:
Rolan L., a 25-year-old, lives in Binarzang Quirino, Isabela with his parents. He believes that there is cooperation between leaders and its constituents to work for the development of their community. Moreover, he said that there is a systematic way of living since most of the residents in the community are involved in farming.

“Patience is the key to success," is a phrase Rolan always puts in mind to be motivated to work harder in order to be successful in life. 

He operates a passenger tricycle in their village and through this, Rolan is able to earn an average daily income of PHP 200. Since, he wants to have another business aside from operating a tricycle, Rolan would like a loan of at least PHP 4,000 to purchase at least two piglets to start a hog raising business. With that, he can have an additional income after three to four months. He plans to use the profit to improve his business until he gets married and has his own family. Rolan will then have enough earnings and a stable business to support them. 

“But before that, I still want to enroll in a vocational course (electrician) to widen my knowledge because I don’t want to be a tricycle driver forever,” Rolan said.

loans.use: Buy piglets to start a hog raising business

loans.name: Bikobila

texts.en:
I. Bikobila was born in 1968 in Khujand. She is divorced with 3 children. She does not have higher education but she has good skills in business, and she has been engaged in business for 14 years. She started business selling small wares but today she has a trade outlet for selling food products (meat products, such as sausages and salami; sour milk products, such as curd and kefir; flour, vegetable oil, juices and sweets). She brings the parcels from Uzbekistan, Russia and the Kyrgyz Republic.

Mrs. I. Bikobila applies to KIVA with the request of a loan of 1500 STJ for 6 months to open a perfumery. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: Open a perfumery

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 39 years old and married, with 4 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She started this business in 2003. She is requesting a loan to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina is 42 years old and is married, with 5 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting this loan to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says, "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Lufuka C –Nambooze Sarah Group

texts.en:
Jovial and friendly, Sarah N. is a matooke (plantain) vendor in Lufuka market. She purchases her stock from up country suppliers three times a week in order to meet the demands of her customers. The business earns her a profit of UGX 80,000 per week from which she pays a market fee of UGX 20,000 per month. She has pride in the business because she began small, but in less than five years, she managed to purchase a plot of land in one of the Kampala suburbs, an achievement deemed impossible through matooke vending. She is therefore using the loan to purchase more bunches of matooke because her customer base increases due to her politeness and excellent customer courtesy.

Sarah is 35 years old and is a single mother of three children between ages 14 and 18. She also looks after her late brother’s three children. Her side income is a small restaurant that she operates in the same market with the help of two lady employees. She looks forward to accumulating some money and starting the construction of a modern residential house on her plot. Her greatest desire is to educate her children to university levels.

loans.use: To purchase more bunches of matooke.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 38 years old and she is a widow with 7 children. She takes care of her children alone. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food like rice, beans, and yams. She is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says, "thanks" to Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and microscope.

loans.name: Rubylyn

texts.en:
“Our family is currently living in a humble house without any electricity,” a mother from Barangay Sisim Alto Tumauini, Isabela narrated. 

Rubylyn D. is 25 years old and married to Lodgie who operates their own passenger tricycle. Their four-year-old daughter gives them inspiration to work harder in order to uplift their life from poverty. 
	 
Rubylyn wants a loan for the improvement of their house and to venture into a hog raising business. She is requesting at least PHP 7,000 to start a new business and to earn more income.

“I hope that through the loan, our life will improve. I know that I must be wise to be able to save for our future including the education of our child," Rubylyn said.  

She believes that there is hope while there is still life.

loans.use: Venture into hog raising business and repair house

loans.name: Kwami

texts.en: Kwami A. is a 37-year-old married father who lives and works in the village of Wome.  In the local language, Ewe, his first name indicates that he was born on Saturday.  To provide for his family, Yawo picks up passengers and their baggage along the road, as seen in this photo, and drops them off at their destination.  This service is always in demand in Wome, as there is no electricity in this village and people must often travel further than walking distance to take care of business.  Yawo has asked for this loan from Kiva so that he can buy a new motorcycle in order to satisfy his customers. With the profits he will earn from his business, Yawo can continue to send his children to school and provide his community with this essential service.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James N. K. started his health clinic in Elburgon, Kenya (near Nakuru) in 1997. For over ten years, he has been providing medical services to the local community, including curative services, out-patient care, family planning, minor surgeries, wound stitching, and circumcisions. Thanks to training from the Kisumu Medical and Education Trust, he is now also able to begin to provide post-abortion care for women. Abortion is illegal in Kenya, but many women receive the procedure illicitly, which can result in severe medical harm and death. James received the K-MET training in order to reduce the number of maternal mortalities by providing care to women who have suffered from botched abortions and counseling them on family planning.

James formerly worked as a nurse for the government, but the pay was not sustainable. He opened a private clinic and has been able to achieve in private practice what he was unable to working for the government. The clinic, open from 8am – 8pm Monday through Saturday, is made up of 3 rooms and James currently employs one other attendant. The patients are from the rural community, often from farming families of low economic status.

James is requesting a loan of 90,000 Kenya Schillings in order to expand the services of his clinic. At present, he is unable to provide immunizations, so he would like to use the loan money to purchase a refrigerator, which will allow him to store the materials needed to give immunizations. The fridge will cost about 15,000 Kenyan Schillings. He also needs equipment for his laboratory, such as a microscope that costs about 25,000 schillings. An expanded laboratory will allow him to conduct more tests and provide a wider range of service. This, alongside providing immunizations, will attract more patients and increase the workload of the clinic. He may need to hire another employee. James is 47 years old, married with 3 children - one girl who is 15 years old and two boys, who are 10 and 2 years old. His goal for the future of the clinic is to include maternity services and perhaps inpatient services as well.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator, microscope, and other medical supplies.

loans.name: Lufuka C- Nansubuga Aisha Group

texts.en:
Aisha N. is 28 years old. She is a single mother of two and a hardworking and polite person. She sells charcoal and also fries snacks like cassava chips, mandazi, pancakes, and samosas in Lufuka. Her businesses are still at a crawling stage and hence earn her UGX 50,000 per week. From the profits, she pays rent of UGX 15,000 per month.

She would use this loan to boost her business by purchasing more sacks of charcoal and also stocking some matooke for sale. Her dreams are to sell second-hand clothes in Owino market, educate her children, and build a decent home for them.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal and stock some matooke to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is a 42-year-old woman, married with 6 children. She sells timber. She started this business in 2004. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more timber to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more timber to sell

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Mrs. Meriam L. is residing at Gata, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, married, with twin children who are both in Grade 2 pupils. Her husband is former clerk employee in Copylandia Company, a supplier of photocopier machines.

Three years ago her husband resigned from his job and decided to engage in photocopier business.  The business started in their house and after a year they decided to rent a space near Saint John High School at Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She personally handles their photocopier business and her husband does the marketing.

She is a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for more than a year now. She is very participative and active in their Weekly Center Meetings. She is now requesting a loan of  PHP 10,000 to purchase photocopier toner and school supplies.

What she plans right now is to renovate her house and be able to have additional stocks and school supplies for their business.

loans.use: Purchase Photocopier Toner & School Supplies

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene is 45 years old and married with 5 children.  She sells timber. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase timber to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase timber to sell

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en:
Khursheda A. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2005. Khursheda is 30 years old. She lives in Khujand. Khursheda is married with 3 children. In the local bazaar, she sells roller towels, jack towels, tea towels and bath towels, fabric, and warm plaids. She has been engaged in this business for 2 years.

Mrs. Khursheda A. is applying to KIVA, requesting a business development loan of 4000 STJ for 2 months for business travel to China (importing a new assortment of goods). She thanks KIVA for support.

loans.use: business travel to China

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
“I dream that my simple business today will improve so I can continue to help my husband in supporting our daily needs,” Nida M. of Magsaysay Naguillan, Isabela said. 

She is married to Felimon, a carpenter, and their marriage is blessed with five children: Leni is the eldest, a 36-year-old high school graduate who is now in Hong Kong working as domestic helper, Liza– a 34-year-old high school graduate, Roselene– a 32-year-old who is married and has finished high school, Binsor– a 30-year-old high school graduate who operates a tricycle, and Michael– a 27-year-old, and also a high school graduate. 

Nida is currently engaged in food vending. Every afternoon, she sells different grilled foods such as barbecued pork, hotdogs, etc. She displays her products in front of their house. Nida wants to increase the quantity of the food she sells to earn more income; so she is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 8,000. She will buy meats and other ingredients for her business.

“With such an amount, I hope to add other varieties of food for the hungry stomach. I am very optimistic that I will earn more to support my family's needs,” she said. 

In addition to her food vending business, Nida also serves as a house caretaker owned by her nieces who are abroad. This serves as an extra income to her.

loans.use: Purchase more meat and ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Zephania

texts.en:
Zephania N. is a 61-year-old nurse who is married with 5 children, all adults. Three of his children are living in the United Kingdom, while 2 are in Nakuru, Kenya.

Zephania opened the Gilgil Community Clinic in Gilgil, Kenya (near Nakuru) in 1992. Before running a private clinic, Zephania worked for the government as a registered nurse, becoming involved in projects of public and clinical education. He stopped working for the government because he believed that people in his area could benefit from his nursing skills in a community health clinic. For 16 years, the women and children in this rural area have continued to benefit from his decision.

The Gilgil Community Clinic offers curative services, maternal and child health care, and reproductive health care including post-abortion care (which helps reduce the maternal mortality rate of women suffering from poorly performed illegal abortions) and family planning.

The clinic consists of four rooms and employs 2 nurses and one cleaner. Zephania wants to expand on the clinic’s laboratory services and hopes to be able to hire a laboratory technician in the future.

Zephania is requesting a loan of 90,000 Kenya Schillings in order to purchase a fridge, drugs for immunizations, equipment for the post abortion care procedures, and a microscope for lab work. With a refrigerator, Zephania will be able to stock the drugs needed for immunizations and offer this new service to his patients.

Zephania has recently been trained by the Kisumu Medical and Education Trust to perform post-abortion care, and he needs certain equipment, such as a speculum, in order to offer this service. Zephania is committed to preventing mother to child transmission of HIV, and a new microscope will allow the clinic to do bloodwork on children and pregnant mothers. At this time, Zephania must send the patients to the subdistrict hospital for bloodwork, where the procedure takes a very long time. Zephania would like to be able to offer all the necessary services under the clinic’s roof, so that there is no need to send patients elsewhere.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator, immunizations, and medical equipment.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Surviving in a difficult area like San Mariano is somehow an achievement. Sometimes the obstacle to a better life is not the conflict between the New Peoples Army and the Military, but the poverty that afflicts the country.

Juanita A. is 59 years old, married to Carlos A. Sr. and luckily, blessed with a son named Carlos A. Jr.  However, due to lack of financial resources, they were not able to send their child to school and he only reached the second year of high school. He is now 30 years old, already married, and works as a farmer to support his own family.  

“For eight years, I have been managing my sari-sari store (a community based store) business. I am now dreaming to expand my enterprise to increase my income and to assist my husband in providing financial support in our farm so that we can avoid asking credits from traders,” Juanita said.

Therefore, she would like to obtain a loan to purchase a variety of stock for her store. Aside from this, Juanita also hopes to maintain her good relationship with her customers and neighbors in the village for she believes that “no man is an island”. She also hopes that this attitude will somehow be adopted by her son and family so that they will have a good future.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products for her store

location.town: Old San Mariano, San Mariano Isabela

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 52 years old and a vegetable vendor. She is married to Juanito, a rice farmer who manages their small rice field in Barangay Minallo Naguillan, Isabela. They have five children:  Lorelie – 32 years old, married, a vocational course graduate; Arnel – 31 years old, married and also finished a vocational course; Girlie – 29 years old, married, high school graduate; Madeline – 25 years old, married, high school graduate; and RJ – 12 years old, a graduating elementary student.  

She started her vegetable vending business when her husband started to plant vegetables in their backyard.  She is in charge of harvesting the vegetables and sells them in the neighborhood and other nearby villages for extra income. 

However, their income is not enough so she is planning to buy a piglet to start her hog raising business, which would increase her income and support the basic needs of their family and education of their youngest child.  She is now asking for financial assistance to pursue her plan. Aside from buying a piglet, she is also planning to use the loan to purchase different vegetables that she can sell in their village.  

“I always believe that our family will survive from the challenges of life, of course through the help of God and the members of our family who serve as my inspirations,” Teresita concluded.

loans.use: To buy a piglet for a hog raising business and purchase different vegetables to sell

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
According to Violeta, the name of their village, Minallo Naguillan, was derived from the Ilocano term “Minalo” (meaning hit by a hard object). Their village is an agricultural area where rice and yellow corn are the major crops of the villagers. She is married to Leny, a carpenter, and they have a four year old son named Mark Justine.

Violeta is engaged in the food vending business, and she sells barbecued pork to her villagers. Her income is too small to support the needs of her family that is why she is planning to venture into a backyard piggery business for extra income. 

She is requesting a loan that will be used to buy two piglets for her backyard piggery. Part of the loan will also be used in her food vending business.

“I always believe that time is valuable.  I grab every opportunity that knocks and take all the risk just to have an income not just for our daily living but also to prepare for the future needs of my family and for my son,” says Violeta.

Violeta also dreams of having her own stall in the public market for her food vending business to provide a sustainable source of income.

loans.use: To buy piglets for her backyard piggery and buy meat for her food business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
“I am thankful that God blessed me with responsible and obedient children.  I am willing to sacrifice everything for them,” Rosita shares.  

Rosita L., together with her husband, children and grandchildren, live happily in Sisim Alto Tumauini, Isabel. They have five children: Rodan – 30 years old and high school graduate; Reynante – 28 years old; Rubilyn Dignos – 26 years old, college graduate, a housewife; Randy – 23 years old, college graduate and now working in Pampanga; and the youngest is Reginard – 20 years old and currently an agriculture student. 

Rosita is a simple vegetable vendor in their village earning an average of PHP600.00 a week. Her husband is engaged in organic rice farming and also serves as a councilor in their village. With this type of business, the couple successfully send all their children to school.  She is hoping that their youngest will also graduate from college in the future.

“My plan is to have a vegetable booth in the public market where I can generate higher income to help my husband earn money to support our daily needs and farm maintenance,” Rosita said. With this in mind, she would like to request a loan to add capital to make her business plan a reality.

loans.use: To acquire a vegetable stall in the public market

loans.name: Roeut's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan with five members from Battambang Province. Mrs. Roeut Y., a 35 year old fish seller, is the leader of the group loan. She owns and runs a small store in the Beung Chok Market. She sells fish, dried fish and fish paste and earns a profit of approximately $3 per day. Mrs. Y.'s husband is Oun Chomnan who is a 34 year old motorcycle taxi driver. They have three children who are currently attending school. Mrs.Y. is requesting a loan to purchase fish for her business. 

There are four other borrowers in this group loan including Sen P. (age 35), Sen L. (age 20), Ly P. (age 28) and Bil S. (age 27). They all require loans to buy more fish for their fish businesses.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius Muuambi M. has been a registered nurse in Kenya since 1985. Married, with three boys of 18, 15, and 14 years old, he worked for years at Telecom as their official nurse. When the company closed, Julius decided to open his own small health clinic.

Now two years old, the Namunyak Medical Clinic serves both children and adults in Gilgil, Kenya (near Nakuru). The clinic provides general outpatient services and reproductive health care, which includes family planning.

The Kisumu Medical and Education Trust recently trained Julius in post-abortion care services for women whose health has suffered from illicit abortions. In order to perform the necessary procedures, Julius now needs to purchase certain instruments. He is requesting a loan of 90,000 Kenya Schillings (1,200 USD) in order to buy instruments, a refrigerator, a microscope for laboratory services, and if funds allow, a television for the clinic’s waiting room. Currently, Julius is forced to send blood samples out to a lab technician to analyze. With a microscope in the clinic, Julius will hire a lab technician full time to do the analysis in-house.

Julius is working alone at the clinic now, but he hopes to employ one or two more people within the next year. His goals for the clinic are presently concerned with its expansion – to have more people working there and more services offered.

loans.use: To purchase medical instruments, a microscope, a refrigerator, and a TV for the waiting room.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en: Teopista N. is a 35 year old business woman. She is married with three school-going children. This hardworking lady owns a depot of soft drinks in Nateete. Running this business efficiently and effectively has enabled her set up a modern residential house where she resides with her family. She is using the loan to purchase a variety of sodas from various bottling companies. Her greatest aspiration at this moment in time is to accumulate some money and purchase a plot of land in one of the Kampala suburbs for the sole aim of constructing rental houses. With such an achievement, she looks forward to meeting her family needs comfortably.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of sodas from various bottling companies.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita L., 31 years old, married and blessed with two children: Crisanto – 12 years old, a Grade 6 student; and Joan – 9 years old, already in the fourth grade. Her husband Jose works as a driver in their community. 

Merlita started her soap vending business one year ago. She decided to have her own business because she wanted to help her husband to earn a living to support the educational needs of their children. She sells detergent and bath soap in their village and most of her customers are women. Merlita earns a minimum of PHP1,500.00 monthly. She budgets her income to re-invest in her business and cover the daily needs of her family. Because she wanted to develop her business, Merlita asked for financial assistance to produce more soap and sell it to nearby villages.  

Her business is really of great help to them since they are able to meet their needs. She is hoping that through her business, they can continue to send their children to school and they can finish their studies. She believes that her strong faith in God will be a great factor in attaining all her hopes in life.

loans.use: To produce more soaps for sale in the community

location.town: Sitio Guingab, Masipi East Cabagan, Isabela

loans.name: Bi Bi Shiren

texts.en:
Bi Bi Shiren lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives with her own nuclear family. She has been doing embroidery for many years. She works in her house and her husband sells what she makes at the bazaar. Her husband is also a taxi driver. Shiren wants to expand her embroidery business and exchange her husband's taxi for a new one.

She has requested an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani with a term of 12 months to enlarge her shop and complete her stock. She wants to say she is sure that after this loan, some changes will come to their life and they can support their family better in future.

Shiren is happy with this loan process in Afghanistan. She would like to thank Kiva for working with AFSG to achieve this wonderful process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To enlarge her business
